point. Required distances are defined at subsection 3-17-6H of this chapter.
RECREATIONAL MOBILE HOME: Shall have the meaning set forth at section 66.0435
(1)(hm), Wisconsin statutes. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII; amd. 2009 Code; Ord.
2013-07, 4-1-2013)
3-17-3: COMMUNITY DESIGN:
   A.   The general pattern of development shall fit topography, requirements
for circulation, and requirements for provision of community facilities and
utilities. Areas for churches, schools, major parks and community facilities
should be located appropriately with respect to the population to be served and
the street and walkway nets. As appropriate, residential areas should merge
into or be insulated from areas devoted to other purposes. They should be
insulated from heavy traffic, concentrations of parking, noise, lights,
commercial and industrial activities. They should merge with parks and other
suitable open areas.
   B.   The street pattern should serve, not shape, the lots in their small
neighborhood groupings. Land devoted to streets should be held to a minimum
compatible with performance of street related functions. Minor streets should
discourage use by through traffic, and no single minor street should serve so
many homes that local traffic is likely to become a problem. Minor streets
should feed at well spaced intervals and well designed intersections into
collector streets and arteries for fast moving traffic. Neither collector nor
arterial streets should have direct entrances from residential lots.
   C.   Blocks should be oriented generally with the long axis in the direction
of principal automotive and pedestrian movement. Blocks should be large enough
and wide enough to provide desirable lot depths, plus interior walkways,
commons, and easements for such utilities as are to be located within the
block.
   D.   The mobile home park should be set in its own environment, rather than
merely running into surrounding uses. It is desirable that it be bordered in a
manner which insulates it from surrounding uses and sets it apart as a
community.
   E.   These standards shall apply to all mobile home parks. Likewise, it will
be necessary to obtain the approval of the board of zoning appeals and common
council for the location and design of any mobile home park on the basis of its
compliance with these standards. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
3-17-4: PARK LICENSE; APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to construct, maintain, operate, alter,
or extend any mobile home park within the limits of the city unless he or she
holds a valid license issued by the city clerk in the name of such person for
the specific construction, alteration or extension proposed.
   B.   All applications for a license shall be filed with the city clerk,
reviewed by the board of zoning appeals and common council and shall contain
the following:
      1.   Name and address of applicant.
      2.   Location and legal description of the mobile home park.
      3.   Complete plans and specifications prepared by a registered engineer
of the proposed park showing, but not limited to, the following:
         a.   The area and dimensions of the tract of land.
         b.   The number and location of all mobile home sites, stands, and the
location of common areas and setback lines.
         c.   The location and width of roadways and walkways.
         d.   Plans and specifications of all utilities including sewage
collection and disposal, stormwater drainage, water distribution and supply,
refuse storage and collection, lighting, electrical, telephone and TV antenna
systems, off street parking.
         e.   Landscaping plans for the entire park, including a planting plan
for the buffer strip.
         f.   Plans, specifications and site plans of all buildings to be
located within the park.
         g.   Such other plans and specifications and information as may
reasonably be required by the enforcing agency.
   C.   No license shall be issued for a mobile home park established after the
effective date hereof unless said development shall contain a minimum of
fifteen (15) acres, but not to exceed fifty (50) acres. A mobile home park
existing on the effective date hereof may be expanded even if such expansion
results in a mobile home park of less than fifteen (15) acres in size, provided
that the expanded portion complies with this chapter and all other applicable
provisions of this code, and further provided that no such park shall exceed
fifty (50) acres in size. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
   D.   Application for new or renewal licenses shall be accompanied by a fee
of two dollars ($2.00) for each space in the existing or proposed park, but not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00). There shall be a fee of ten dollars ($10.00)
for the transfer of a license. Such parks shall comply with Wisconsin
administrative code SPS326. (Ord. 2013-07, 4-1-2013)
   E.   Applications for renewal of licenses shall contain any change in the
information submitted since the original license was issued, or the latest
renewal granted.
   F.   Licensees of mobile home parks and owners of land on which are parked
any mobile homes shall furnish information to the city clerk and city assessor
on such homes added to their park, within five (5) days after arrival of such
home, on forms prescribed by the Wisconsin department of revenue and furnished
by the city clerk in accordance with section 66.0435, Wisconsin statutes. All
information required on the form, including the full purchase price including
sales tax and furnishings, shall be provided to the fullest extent possible and
no person shall omit any of such information. No person shall knowingly falsify
any such information.
   G.   Each mobile home located in the city shall pay a monthly parking fee as
determined in accordance with section 66.0435, Wisconsin statutes. Said fees
shall be paid to the city treasurer-comptroller on or before the tenth day of
the month following the month for which such fees are due. (1975 Code Ch. 13
§ XVIII; amd. 2009 Code)
   H.   The monthly parking fees referred to in subsection G of this section
shall not be charged for the parking of any mobile home for a period of one
week or less, nor for any space occupied by a mobile home accompanied by an
automobile for an accumulative period not to exceed sixty (60) days in any
twelve (12) months, if the occupants are tourists or vacationists. The licensee
of such park shall keep a record of persons claiming exemption pursuant to this
section, containing the signature of such claimant and in a form approved by
the city treasurer- comptroller.
   I.   Licenses shall expire each year on June 30 and may be renewed annually
thereafter by any licensee after approval of the common council and upon
payment of the annual license fee. Upon such renewal, the city clerk shall
issue a certificate renewing the license for another year unless sooner
revoked. The application for renewal shall be in writing signed by the
applicant on forms furnished by the city clerk.
   J.   No license shall be issued or transferred unless all monthly parking
fees attributable to the park from all preceding months have been fully paid as
required by this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
3-17-5: PARK INSPECTIONS:
   A.   No mobile home park license shall be issued until the city clerk has
notified the police department, health officer, fire department and building
inspector or their authorized agents, of the application, and these officials
shall inspect or cause to be inspected each application and the premises to
determine whether the applicant and the premises on which the mobile homes are
or will be located comply with the regulations, ordinances and laws applicable
thereto. These officials shall furnish to the city clerk the results of their
inspections and statement as to whether the applicant and the premises meet all
applicable requirements.
   B.   No license shall be renewed without a reinspection of the premises by
the enforcing agencies described at subsection A of this section.
   C.   An enforcing agency (see subsection A of this section) shall have the
power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the
purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement
of this chapter.
   D.   An enforcing agency (see subsection A of this section) shall have the
power to inspect the register containing a record of all residents of the
mobile home park.
   E.   It is the duty of every resident of a mobile home park to give the
management thereof or his designated agent access to any part of the mobile
home stand or common area at reasonable times for the purpose of making such
repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this chapter.
   F.   Whenever, upon inspection of any mobile home park, the enforcing agency
finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of this
chapter, the enforcing agency shall give notice in writing to the person to
whom the license was issued that, unless such conditions or practices are
corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in the notice by the
enforcing agency, the license may be suspended or revoked. (1975 Code Ch. 13
§ XVIII)
3-17-6: PARKS; GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
Any individual making application for a license to construct a mobile home park
shall meet the following design and system requirements:
   A.   Site Location: A mobile home park shall be located only upon property
designated for that use by the board of zoning appeals and the common council.
   B.   Restrictions: Restrictions upon mobile home parks shall be:
      1.   No part of any mobile home park shall be used for nonresidential
purposes except such uses that are required for the direct servicing and well
being of park residents, and for the management and maintenance of the park.
(1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
      2.   No recreational mobile home shall be permitted in the mobile home
park. (Ord. 2013-07, 4-1-2013)
      3.   The condition of soil, groundwater level, drainage and topography
shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the
occupants. No portion of the park subject to predictable sudden flooding or
erosion shall be used for any purpose which would expose persons or property to
hazards.
      4.   No part of any mobile home park shall be used for the storage or
sale of mobile homes, except that a sale of a mobile home is permitted,
provided that the mobile home is sited on a mobile home stand and is connected
to utilities.
   C.   Mobile Home Stands: Mobile home stand regulations are as follows:
      1.   The area of the mobile home stand shall be improved to provide
adequate support for the placement and tie down of the mobile home, thereby
securing the superstructure against uplift, sliding, rotation and overturning;
      2.   Anchors and tie downs shall be installed on all mobile homes as per
manufacturer's or state specifications. The mobile home park owner shall ensure
that all mobile homes are anchored and tied down.
   D.   Streets: All mobile home parks shall be provided with safe and
convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads to each
mobile home stand. Such access shall be provided by streets, driveways or other
means.
      1.   Entrances: Entrances to mobile home parks shall have direct
connections to a public street and shall be designed to allow free movement of
traffic on such adjacent public street. No parking shall be permitted on the
entrance street for a distance of seventy five feet (75') from its point of
beginning.
      2.   Internal Streets: Internal streets shall have the following
specifications:
         a.   No street grade shall be more than eight percent (8%).
         b.   Roadways shall be of adequate width to accommodate anticipated
traffic and in any case shall meet the following minimum requirements:
            (1)   Two-way streets must be at least thirty two feet (32') wide,
if parking is permitted on both sides, twenty four feet (24') wide if parking
is permitted only on one side, and eighteen feet (18') wide if parking on the
street is prohibited.
            (2)   A one-way street shall be at least twenty four feet (24')
wide if parking is permitted on both sides, eighteen feet (18') wide if parking
is permitted on one side, and fourteen feet (14') wide if parking on the street
is prohibited.
            (3)   Dead end streets (cul-de-sacs) shall be limited in length to
five hundred feet (500'), and shall be provided at the closed end with a
turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least sixty feet (60').
            (4)   Street intersections should generally be at right angles.
Curb radius at the intersection shall not be less than twenty five feet (25').
Offsets at intersections and intersections of more than two (2) streets at one
point should be avoided.
            (5)   All streets shall be provided with a paved concrete or
blacktop surface which shall be durable and well drained under normal use and
weather conditions. The surface shall be adequately maintained. (1975 Code
Ch. 13 § XVIII)
            (6)   All streets shall be constructed with a curb and gutter
approved by the director of public works. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII; amd. 2009
Code)
      3.   Lighting: Adequate lighting shall be provided for all streets within
the mobile home parks so as to protect motorists, pedestrians and the residents
of the park.
   E.   Accessory Structures: Accessory structures shall not be used as
complete, independent living units with permanent provisions for sleeping,
cooking and sanitation. Such structures shall be erected, constructed or
occupied in a mobile home park as directed by the management of the mobile home
park, as required by the local enforcing agency, and as specified herein:
      1.   Accessory structures shall be designed in a manner that will enhance
the appearance of the mobile home park.
      2.   Accessory structures shall not obstruct required openings for light
and ventilation of the mobile home, and shall not prevent inspection of mobile
home equipment and utility connections.
      3.   Construction and electrical installations, unless otherwise
specified, shall comply with the building and electrical codes of the city.
(1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
      4.   Detached accessory structures shall be included and approved as part
of the original or revised mobile home park plan. If such plan has not been
approved, a maximum of one accessory structure per mobile home stand will be
allowed if a setback of ten feet (10') is maintained to adjacent mobile homes
and five feet (5') to the site's mobile home. Detached accessory structures
shall also meet the setback requirements of subsection H of this section. (1975
Code Ch. 13 § XVIII; amd. Ord. 2013-07, 4-1-2013)
   F.   Density: Each mobile home site shall not be less than five thousand
five hundred (5,500) square feet in area.
   G.   Required Separation Between Mobile Homes: The minimum open space
distance between mobile homes shall be twenty feet (20'), except that sixteen
feet (16') will be allowed from the narrow ends of two (2) mobile homes. An
attached accessory structure such as an awning, cabana, storage cabinet,
carport, windbreak, porch or any other covered or enclosed addition to the
mobile home shall, for the purposes of separation requirements, be considered a
part of the mobile home. Uncovered porches, patios, decks and steps to mobile
home entrances may extend eight feet (8') into the required open space
distance. Enclosed porches, windbreaks, storage areas or other nonhabitable
areas to the main entrance may extend four feet (4') into the required open
space distance; provided, that not more than thirty two (32) square feet of
such area is within such space.
   H.   Setback Required:
      1.   There shall be minimum distance of twenty five feet (25') from any
mobile home to any mobile home park property boundary line, including boundary
lines along streets. This distance may be reduced to twenty feet (20') in
existing parks where existing mobile homes have already established a distance
of less than twenty five feet (25'). (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
      2.   There shall be a minimum distance of fifteen feet (15') from the
mobile home stand and the face of the curb of the abutting mobile home park
street. (Ord. 2013-07, 4-1-2013)
      3.   No mobile home shall be located closer than sixty feet (60') from
any community building, including any washrooms, toilet or laundry facilities
within the mobile home park.
   I.   Greenbelt Landscaping Requirements: All mobile home parks shall have a
greenbelt or buffer strip not less than five feet (5') wide along all
boundaries. All mobile home parks shall be provided with solid, effective
screening of trees or shrubs along the property boundary line separating the
park and such adjacent properties, except for boundaries that abut a public
street; provided, however, that if park boundaries abut more than one public
street, the above screening shall be required for all but one boundary abutting
a public street. The screening of trees or shrubs shall be established within
six (6) months after issuance of the license for the occupation of such mobile
home park and shall consist of a permanent planting of trees and shrubs so
arranged and in sufficient numbers so as to form a solid wall of plant
material. Such planting shall be a minimum height of two feet (2') except where
line of sight vision is necessary for pedestrian or vehicular traffic safety.
If fences are also erected, they shall be erected to a height of at least six
feet (6') except where line of sight is necessary for pedestrian or vehicular
traffic safety.
   J.   Recreation Area: At least five percent (5%) of a mobile home park shall
be devoted to recreational or common open space use for the enjoyment of the
occupants of the park. Such open space should, where conditions permit, be
centrally located so as to be free from traffic hazards.
   K.   Off Street Parking Requirements:
      1.   Occupant Parking: A minimum of two (2) parking spaces shall be
provided for each mobile home stand, and this space shall be located within
thirty feet (30') of the mobile home stand. Parking in tandem is permitted.
Each such parking space shall be constructed of concrete or blacktop surface.
      2.   Parking Restrictions: Parking of boats, trailers, campers,
snowmobiles or other similar vehicles shall be restricted to an area provided
by the park management specifically for that purpose or on the parking space
referred to at subsection K1 of this section.
      3.   Front Yard Parking: There shall be compliance with the front yard
parking regulations at title 4, chapter 6 of this code.
   L.   Signs: No signs shall be erected in mobile home parks except traffic
signs, signs pertaining to the lease, hire or sale of individual mobile homes
not more than two (2) square feet in area and one mobile home park
identification sign not more than thirty two (32) square feet in area at each
park entrance. There shall be compliance with the requirements of title 9,
chapter 6 of this code.
   M.   Fire Protection: Fire protection precautions shall be as follows:
      1.   Fires shall be made only in barbecue pits, fireplaces, stoves or
other equipment intended for such purposes. Incinerators shall be prohibited.
(1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
      2.   Portable fire extinguishers shall be kept in service buildings and
shall be maintained in good operating condition. They shall be rated as
recommended by NFPA standards. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII; amd. 2009 Code)
      3.   Fire hydrants shall be located within four hundred feet (400') of
any mobile home, service building or other structure in the park. Each such
fire hydrant shall be served by a minimum six inch (6") water main.
   N.   Public Utility System: All utility service systems shall be installed
and maintained in accordance with applicable state or local codes and
regulations governing such systems.
      1.   Mobile home service outlets shall be provided at each mobile home
stand for electricity, telephone and natural gas.
      2.   All utility service lines shall be located underground within the
mobile home park, except in existing parks these utility service lines may be
aboveground.
   O.   Solid Waste Disposal:
      1.   All garbage not disposed of through a garbage disposal unit
connected with the sewage system shall be kept in separate, leakproof,
nonabsorbent containers equipped with tightfitting covers unless otherwise
protected from flies and insects. Garbage cans shall be maintained in a clean
and sanitary condition. The use of wooden or paper containers for garbage is
prohibited. Flytight containers with covers shall be used for cans, bottles,
and other rubbish.
      2.   Garbage, trash and recyclables shall be collected at least one time
per week. All refuse shall be stored, collected and transported in covered
vehicles or covered containers.
   P.   Service Buildings; Community Facilities:
      1.   The requirements of this subsection shall apply to service
buildings, recreation buildings and other community service facilities such as:
         a.   Management offices, repair shops and storage areas.
         b.   Sanitary facilities.
         c.   Laundry facilities.
         d.   Indoor recreation areas.
      2.   All portions of a permanent structure shall be properly protected
from damage by ordinary uses and by decay, corrosion, termites and other
destructive elements. Exterior portions shall be of such material and be so
constructed and protected as to prevent entrance or penetration of moisture and
weather.
      3.   All rooms containing sanitary or laundry facilities shall:
         a.   Have sound resistant walls extending to the ceiling between male
and female sanitary facilities. Walls and partitions around showers, bathtubs,
lavatories and other plumbing fixtures shall be constructed of dense,
nonabsorbent, waterproof material or covered with moisture resistant material.
         b.   Have at least one window or skylight facing directly to the
outdoors. The minimum aggregate gross area of windows for each required room
shall not be less than ten percent (10%) of the floor area served by them.
         c.   Have at least one window which can be easily opened, or a
mechanical device which will adequately ventilate the room.
      4.   Toilets shall be located in separate compartments equipped with
self-closing doors. Shower stalls shall be of the individual type. The rooms
shall be screened to prevent direct view of the interior when the exterior
doors are open.
      5.   Illumination levels shall be maintained as follows:
         a.   General seeing tasks: Five (5) foot-candles.
         b.   Laundry room work areas: Forty (40) foot-candles.
         c.   Toilet room, in front of mirror: Forty (40) foot-candles.
      6.   Hot and cold water shall be furnished to every lavatory, sink,
bathtub, shower and laundry fixture, and cold water shall be furnished to every
water closet and urinal. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
3-17-7: RESPONSIBILITIES OF MANAGEMENT:
   A.   The park management shall maintain an office in the park. A copy of the
park license and of this chapter shall be posted therein and the park register
shall at all times be kept in the office.
   B.   It is the duty of the park owner or operator, together with any
attendants or persons in charge, to:
      1.   Keep a register of all occupants, to be open at all times to
inspection by local, county, state and federal officers which shall show for
all occupants:
         a.   Name and address.
         b.   State of legal residence.
         c.   Persons claiming exemption from parking fees.
      2.   Maintain the park in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all
times.
      3.   Cooperate with the health officer in all cases of persons or animals
infected or suspected of being infected with any reportable communicable
disease.
      4.   Ensure that the provisions of this chapter are complied with and
enforced, and report promptly to the proper authorities any violation of this
chapter or other violations of law which may come to his attention.
      5.   Install and maintain smoke detectors as required by state law in all
mobile homes owned by the park owner or operator.
      6.   Collect and pay to the city treasurer-comptroller the monthly
parking fees called for in subsection 3-17-4G of this chapter and shall keep a
record of the persons paying such fees and the amount paid. (1975 Code Ch. 13
§ XVIII)
3-17-8: RESPONSIBILITY OF RESIDENT:
It is the duty of the occupants of mobile homes to:
   A.   Maintain their site in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all
times.
   B.   Abide by all applicable state and city regulations and rules
established by the park management. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
3-17-9: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction,
be subject to a forfeiture not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense. Each day during which any violation continues shall be deemed to
constitute a separate offense. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
3-17-10: LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
The common council is authorized to revoke or suspend any license or permit
issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter in accordance with section
66.0435, Wisconsin statutes. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII; amd. 2009 Code)
3-17-11: MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS REGARDING MOBILE HOMES:
   A.   Prior Existence Of Park: Except as noted at subsection D of this
section, mobile home parks in lawful existence prior to the effective date
hereof or in lawful existence prior to annexation to the city are exempt from
the provisions of this chapter; provided, however, that any expansion or
modification of such park shall be in accordance with these regulations.
   B.   Mobile Homes Outside Park: No person shall hereafter park, locate or
place any mobile home outside of a licensed mobile home park in the city,
except unoccupied mobile homes may be parked on the lawfully situated premises
of a vehicle service business for purposes of servicing or making necessary
repairs, or on a lawfully zoned premises for purposes of sales display. This
subsection shall not apply to a mobile home that meets the definition of
"manufactured home" in section
10-1-4 of this code, and is used as a residential building on a zoning lot.
   C.   Parking On Street: No person shall stop, stand or park a mobile home on
any street, alley or highway within the city in violation of chapters 340 to
348 of the Wisconsin statutes or the traffic ordinances and regulations of the
city.
   D.   Fire Protection: Where subsection 3-17-6M3 of this chapter does not
apply due to the fact that the mobile home park was in lawful existence prior
to the effective date hereof or prior to annexation to the city, the fire chief
may order the mobile home park to install fire hydrants within four hundred
feet (400') of every mobile home stand, service building or other structure in
the park and provide that said order be complied with within two (2) years,
where in his discretion and opinion fire protection cannot otherwise be
adequately provided. Such order shall be reviewed by the common council prior
to implementation of the order if an application for such review is made by the
owner within thirty (30) days of the order from the fire chief.
   E.   Appeals: Appeals for variance from the regulations of this chapter may
be made to the board of zoning appeals by the same rights and procedures
governing zoning appeals. Appeals shall first be reviewed by the building
inspector's office which shall advise the board of its findings prior to the
hearing. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
3-17-12: VALIDITY:
If any subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter is for
any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the decision of any court
of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of any
other subsection, sentence, phrase or portion thereof. The common council
hereby declares that it would have passed such section and each subsection,
sentence, clause, phrase or portion thereof irrespective of the fact that any
one or more subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases thereof may be declared
invalid or unconstitutional. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XVIII)
CHAPTER 18
SOLID WASTE COLLECTION
SECTION:
3-18-1: License Requirements; Regulations
3-18-2: Compliance With Rules
3-18-3: Suspension Or Revocation Of License
3-18-1: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS; REGULATIONS:
   A.   State And City Licenses Required; Application; Fees:
      1.   All persons, firms and corporations or their agents engaged in the
business of collecting or transporting solid waste for disposal purposes from
properties within the city, or within other municipalities authorized by
agreement with the city shall first secure a solid waste collection license.
(1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXII; amd. 2009 Code)
      2.   Applicants for a solid waste collection license must show evidence
of a current, valid state of Wisconsin department of natural resources permit
for collection and transportation of solid waste.
      3.   All applicants shall pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per
year, plus twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year for each vehicle in excess of
one used in the business of solid waste collection. Licenses shall be for a
period of one year and shall expire on June 30 of each year.
      4.   Applications for solid waste collection licenses shall contain the
following information:
         a.   Name of owner or owners of the business.
         b.   Name of the business.
         c.   Address used for business purposes.
         d.   Description of all vehicles used in the business, to include
model and make of vehicle, type of container used for carrying solid waste on
the vehicle and license number. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXII)
   B.   Vehicles And Containers: Vehicles and containers used for the
collection and transportation of garbage and trash shall be covered, leakproof,
durable and of easily cleanable construction. These shall be cleaned frequently
to prevent nuisances or insect breeding and shall be maintained in good repair.
Vehicles or containers so used shall be loaded and moved in such a manner that
the contents will not fall, leak or spill therefrom and shall be covered when
necessary to prevent blowing of material. Where spillage does occur, the
material shall be picked up immediately by the licensee and returned to the
vehicle and the area properly cleaned.
   C.   Supervision Or Revocation Of License: The public works director shall
supervise the licensing provisions of this chapter and shall direct or perform
the necessary inspection to enforce the provisions of this chapter. (1975 Code
Ch. 13 § XXII; amd. 2009 Code)
3-18-2: COMPLIANCE WITH RULES:
All licensees shall comply with the rules regulating the use of the city solid
waste collection site. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXII; amd. 2009 Code)
3-18-3: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Such licenses may be temporarily suspended by the public works director for a
violation of any provision of this chapter or revoked after an opportunity for
a hearing by the common council of the city upon ten (10) days' notice
personally served upon the licensee. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXII; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 19
AUTOMOTIVE SALVAGE YARDS
SECTION:
3-19-1: Annual Fee
3-19-2: Application
3-19-3: Terms And Conditions
3-19-4: Enforcement
3-19-5: Violation
3-19-1: ANNUAL FEE:
An automotive salvage license may be obtained by application to the common
council accompanied by a twenty five dollar ($25.00) annual fee each July 1.
(1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXIII)
3-19-2: APPLICATION:
Each application for an automotive salvage license must be accompanied by a
location sketch in duplicate, drawn to scale, showing the location, actual
shape and dimensions of the lot in question, the exact size and location of the
lot proposed or existing automotive salvage yard, including the location and
dimensions of any buildings or fences thereon. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXIII)
3-19-3: TERMS AND CONDITIONS:
Applications for automotive salvage licenses shall not be granted by the common
council, and such license shall be suspended or revoked, whenever the applicant
or licensee fails to comply with any of the following requirements:
   A.   Any automotive salvage yard must be enclosed by a solid screen or fence
maintained in proper condition or repair which shall be not less than six feet
(6') nor more than ten feet (10') in height.
   B.   The contents of an automotive salvage yard must not be accumulated to
heights greater than that of the screen or fence enclosing said yard.
   C.   Each enclosed automotive salvage yard must be located at least seven
hundred fifty feet (750') from the centerline of any state trunk or federal
highway; at least fifty feet (50') from the centerline of any other highway; at
least twelve feet (12') from the side and rear lot lines of abutting
nonresidential property; and at least twenty five feet (25') from the side and
rear lot lines of abutting residential property.
   D.   Burning of fuel, lubricants, tires, upholstery or other vehicle and
equipment salvage is strictly prohibited.
   E.   Storage of petroleum products in open containers or in any manner
contrary to state or city fire codes is prohibited.
   F.   Dumping of petroleum products on the ground or in open sumps is
prohibited. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXIII)
   G.   Noxious weeds as defined in chapter 66.0407, Wisconsin statutes, are
prohibited.
   H.   Accumulation of material harboring rodents, vermin or other pests
defined as health hazards is prohibited. (1975 Code Ch. 13 § XXIII; amd. 2009
Code)
3-19-4: ENFORCEMENT:
The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the mayor or by his
delegate. Refusal to permit inspection, or the barring of enforcement officials
in the course of their duties, at any reasonable time is prohibited. (1975 Code
Ch. 13 § XXIII)
3-19-5: VIOLATION:
The provisions of this chapter shall be considered to be violated: a) whenever
there is failure to cease and dismantle operation of an automotive salvage yard
after license revocation; b) whenever there is a failure to correct ordered
deficiencies; c) whenever there is an expansion of licensed operations without
specific approval; d) or whenever provisions described in section
3-19-3 of this chapter are violated. Continued violation of this chapter shall
be considered as creating a public nuisance and may be abated or removed and
the penalties imposed as provided in title 4, chapter 2 of this code. (1975
Code Ch. 13 § XXIII)
CHAPTER 20
SECONDHAND ARTICLE DEALERS AND SECONDHAND JEWELRY DEALERS
SECTION:
3-20-1: Licensing And Regulation
3-20-1: LICENSING AND REGULATION:
The provisions of section 134.71, Wisconsin statutes relating to the licensing
and regulation of secondhand article dealers and secondhand jewelry dealers are
incorporated herein by reference. (Ord. 2007-02, 1-15-2007)
CHAPTER 21
CHICKENS
SECTION:
3-21-1: Purpose
3-21-2: Definitions
3-21-3: License Required
3-21-4: Fees
3-21-5: Property Requirements And Coop Design
3-21-6: Conditions For Keeping And Sanitation
3-21-7: Inspection And Enforcement
3-21-8: Other Methods Not Excluded
3-21-9: Severability
3-21-10: Violation And Penalty
3-21-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to outline conditions under which city residents
on certain residential properties may safely keep and maintain a limited number
of chickens to provide eggs for household use; to assure appropriate chicken
coops or structures in which to house chickens; and to protect the health,
safety, and welfare of the general population of the city of Menomonie. (Ord.
2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-2: DEFINITIONS:
ABUTTING PROPERTY: All lots that the applicant's property comes into contact
with at one or more points, except for lots that are separated from the
applicant's property by a public or private street or public alley.
CHICKEN: A female gallinaceous bird or hen of any age, including chicks. This
definition does not include other kinds of fowl, including guinea hens, ducks,
quail, pheasant, geese, turkeys, peacocks, emus or ostriches.
COOP: An enclosed structure, building or pen within which chickens roost or are
housed.
LOT: As defined in section
10-1-4 of this code.
REAR YARD: As defined in section
10-1-4 of this code.
SINGLE-FAMILY DWELLING: As defined in section
10-1-4 of this code.
TWO-FAMILY DWELLING: As defined in section
10-1-4 of this code. (Ord. 2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall own, harbor, keep or maintain chickens within the city
without first obtaining a license, except as provided in subsection 10-4-2K of
this code.
   B.   The license year shall commence on April 1, and shall end on March 31,
and shall be renewed annually.
   C.   Applications shall be made to the city clerk.
   D.   Applicants shall state on the licensing application a plan to dispose
of chicken manure in a safe and adequate manner.
   E.   Applicants shall state on the licensing application a coop design and
materials plan that is consistent with the requirements of this chapter.
   F.   Applicants shall provide a site plan with the license application that
is consistent with the requirements of this chapter.
   G.   No license shall be issued until the building inspection department
inspects the property and determines that there has been compliance with the
requirements of this chapter.
   H.   The applicant shall be the property owner or tenant with written
consent of property owner on license application.
   I.   The license shall not be transferable. (Ord. 2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-4: FEES:
   A.   The fee for the initial license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) together
with a twenty five dollar ($25.00) building permit fee. The annual license
renewal fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00).
   B.   A late fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed for any
licensee who fails to renew a license prior to the commencement of the new
license year. This late fee charge shall be in addition to the ten dollar
($10.00) annual license renewal fee.
   C.   License fees shall not be prorated or refundable. (Ord. 2012-09, 6-4-
2012)
3-21-5: PROPERTY REQUIREMENTS AND COOP DESIGN:
   A.   Property Requirements:
      1.   Chickens regulated by this chapter shall only be permitted on
property upon which a single-family dwelling or a two-family dwelling is
located, regardless of the zoning district designation of the property (other
than in an agricultural district where the owning, harboring, keeping or
maintaining of chickens is a permitted use and is not subject to the provisions
of this chapter).
      2.   Chickens shall not be harbored, kept or maintained on a vacant lot.
      3.   All coops shall be located in a rear yard.
      4.   A coop and any attached enclosure shall be located a minimum of
twenty five feet (25') from a residential structure on an abutting property and
a minimum of ten feet (10') from the licensee's property line.
   B.   Coop Design:
      1.   All chickens shall be kept and maintained within a cross ventilated
and roofed coop in compliance with this chapter.
      2.   The coop structural floor area shall not exceed sixty four (64)
square feet and the height of the coop shall not exceed eight feet (8') as
measured vertically from the coop's grade level to the outside highest point of
the coop.
      3.   The coop shall either be:
         a.   Elevated with a clear open space of twenty four inches (24")
between the ground surface and the floor of the coop; or
         b.   The coop's foundation shall be constructed of concrete or
naturally decay resistant or pressure treated wood with preservative on the
ground surface.
      4.   All coops, including an attached coop enclosure, shall be enclosed
with wire netting or equivalent material including a protective overhead that
will prevent chickens from escaping the coop or the attached enclosure. Wire
netting shall not exceed eight feet (8') as measured vertically from the coop's
grade level to the outside highest point of the coop.
      5.   All coops shall provide a minimum of three (3) square feet per
chicken.
      6.   All coop floors shall be composed of a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent
surface. A wood or dirt floor is not acceptable.
      7.   There must be at least one nesting box per two (2) chickens.
      8.   Exterior finish materials shall be typical residential type
construction materials as approved by the uniform dwelling code.
      9.   There must be a minimum of one square foot of window for each ten
(10) square feet of wall space.
      10.   Coops shall provide elevated perches to ensure chickens are able to
rest in their natural roosting position. (Ord. 2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-6: CONDITIONS FOR KEEPING AND SANITATION:
   A.   Conditions For Keeping: A person owning, harboring, keeping or
maintaining chickens pursuant to this chapter:
      1.   Shall keep, harbor or maintain not more than five (5) chickens.
      2.   Shall keep, harbor or maintain chickens within a coop or attached
coop enclosure at all times.
      3.   Shall not keep, harbor or maintain any roosters or male chickens.
      4.   Shall not sell any eggs on site.
      5.   Shall not slaughter any chickens.
      6.   No person shall use any chickens for fighting.
      7.   Shall not engage in chicken breeding or fertilizer production for
commercial purposes.
      8.   All chickens shall be provided access to food and clean water at all
times.
      9.   Chickens ill with an infectious disease capable of being transmitted
from bird to bird or from birds to humans, including, but not limited to,
salmonella and avian influenza, are prohibited and shall be immediately killed
at a veterinarian's office or removed from the city and humanely killed outside
of the city.
      10.   Deceased chickens should be disposed of immediately in a safe
manner by placing the deceased chicken in a sealed bag and placing it in a
trash receptacle with a lid.
   B.   Sanitation:
      1.   Chickens and their coops shall be kept and maintained at all times
in outdoor areas and shall not be permitted inside a residential premises or
dwelling.
      2.   Chicken feed shall be stored and kept in containers which make the
feed unavailable to rodents, vermin, wild birds and predators.
      3.   All coops and rear yards where chickens are kept, harbored or
maintained shall be reasonably free from substances, including, but not limited
to, chicken manure, such that it does not cause the air or environment to
become noxious or offensive or to be in such condition as to promote the
breeding of flies, mosquitoes, or other insects, or to provide habitat,
breeding or feeding place for rodents or other animals, or otherwise be
injurious to public health.
      4.   Provision must be made for the storage and removal of chicken
manure. All stored manure shall be covered by a fully enclosed structure with a
roof or lid over the entire structure. All other manure not used for composting
or fertilizing shall be removed. In addition, the henhouse, chicken pen and
surrounding area must be kept free from trash and accumulated droppings.
Uneaten feed shall be removed in a timely manner. (Ord. 2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-7: INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The building inspection department and the police department shall have
the power, whenever it may deem reasonably necessary, and consistent with the
requirements of statutory and constitutional law, to enter a building,
structure, or property related to a license under this chapter to ascertain
whether the license holder is in compliance with this chapter. The above listed
departments may issue compliance orders and citations pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter, this code and state law.
   B.   Violations of this chapter may constitute a public nuisance under title
4, chapter 2 of this code, or under chapter 823, Wisconsin statutes.
   C.   A license issued hereunder may be revoked by the city clerk upon
determination that the licensee has failed to comply with the provisions of
this chapter, this code, or state law, or the chickens or premises have been
declared a public nuisance. (Ord. 2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-8: OTHER METHODS NOT EXCLUDED:
The provisions of this chapter are not exclusive and may be used in combination
with each other or with any other section of this code or state statute
applicable to this subject matter. (Ord. 2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-9: SEVERABILITY:
If any section of this chapter is found to be unconstitutional or otherwise
invalid, the validity of the remaining sections shall not be affected. (Ord.
2012-09, 6-4-2012)
3-21-10: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, forfeit not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day of
violation, if applicable, together with the costs of prosecution. (Ord. 2012-
09, 6-4-2012)
CHAPTER 22
HOMELESS SHELTER FACILITIES
SECTION:
3-22-1: License Required; Definitions
3-22-2: License Fee
3-22-3: Application For License
3-22-4: Inspection
3-22-5: Additional Regulations
3-22-6: Notice Of Violation
3-22-7: Penalty
3-22-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; DEFINITIONS:
No person, firm, corporation or other organization shall operate or maintain a
homeless shelter facility in the city without first having obtained a license
thereof as required under this chapter.
HOMELESS SHELTER FACILITY: Any facility with overnight sleeping accommodations,
the primary purpose of which is to provide temporary shelter for the homeless
in general or for specific populations of the homeless. (Ord. 2013-20, 11-18-
2013)
3-22-2: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   No license shall be issued or renewed for each homeless shelter
facility unless the complete application form is accompanied by payment of a
license fee of thirty dollars ($30.00).
   B.   If an inspection is made of any premises which is not licensed under
this chapter or has not been licensed under this chapter, the applicant shall
pay an inspection fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for the inspection in addition
to the license fee. If a transfer of license pursuant to subsection 3-22-5J of
this chapter occurs, a license transfer fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be
required. (Ord. 2013-20, 11-18-2013)
3-22-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application shall be made on a written form provided by the inspection
department. The application shall be submitted to the building inspector
annually. A license shall have a term of one year from December 1 to November
30 of the following year. Licenses shall be issued by the building inspector
after an inspection determines that the premises in question are in compliance
with this chapter.
   A.   All applications for a homeless shelter facility license shall be
received prior to the December 1 license year starting date for each year. Any
application received by the inspection department on or after December 1 or
postmarked prior to December 1 but received after December 5 shall be assessed
a late fee charge of ten dollars ($10.00).
   B.   All owners or agents shall schedule a time for inspection to occur
within thirty (30) days of the starting date of the new license year. The owner
or agent shall be present for an inspection to occur. One reinspection, if
required, shall be scheduled by the owner or agent to occur prior to January 31
without cost. Any inspections scheduled contrary to the above dates will
require a twenty five dollar ($25.00) late inspection fee for each inspection
and/or reinspection. For any new written requirement issued during that license
year after the initial inspection, the reinspection for that new written
requirement only shall be without cost.
   C.   License fees shall be paid at the time of application.
   D.   Late inspection fees shall be paid prior to time of inspection. (Ord.
2013-20, 11-18-2013)
3-22-4: INSPECTION:
The building inspector shall not issue any homeless shelter facility license to
any premises which:
   A.   Is in violation of any applicable provisions of the Wisconsin building,
plumbing or electrical codes.
   B.   Does not comply with the city zoning ordinances concerning off street
parking requirements.
   C.   Does not comply with the front yard parking ordinance as required by
section
4-6-3 of this code.
   D.   Does not have smoke detectors installed and maintained in the following
locations within the homeless shelter facility:
      1.   At the head of every open stair on each floor level;
      2.   At the door leading to every enclosed stair on each floor level,
including the basement; and
      3.   In each sleeping area.
   E.   Does not have fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of 3A40BC
installed and available to all occupants within a walking distance of seventy-
five (75) feet from any location within the homeless shelter facility. (Ord.
2013-20, 11-18-2013; Ord. 2019-19, 9-3-2019)
3-22-5: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS:
The following requirements shall be met at all times:
   A.   Garbage Disposal: Every homeless shelter facility shall be supplied
with adequate garbage and rubbish disposal facilities or garbage and rubbish
storage containers.
   B.   Dwellings Above First Floor: Dwelling units which are above the first
story will be permitted to use a secondary exit which utilizes a flat roof,
deck or platform a minimum of four feet by six feet (4' x 6'), supported by
columns or brackets, and is provided with a three foot six inch (3'6") high
protective rail together with two (2) uniformly spaced intermediate rails.
   C.   Circuit Breakers: Branch circuits shall be protected by circuit
breakers, or by S-type or equivalent safety type, tamperproof fuses not to
exceed the amp capacity of the smallest wire in the circuit.
   D.   Electrical Outlets; Connecting To Appliances:
      1.   No duplex electric outlet shall serve more than two (2) major
appliances. All major appliances shall be plugged directly into an outlet
without the use of an extension cord. Small convenience appliances can use an
extension cord of no more than six feet (6') in length with only one small
convenience appliance per extension cord, and no more than two (2) extension
cords per outlet; provided, however, that more than one small convenience
appliance may be plugged into a multiple outlet surge protector with a circuit
breaker without the use of an extension cord.
      2.   "Major appliance" is an appliance which is stationary, not moved
daily, such as a clothes washer, clothes dryer, stove, refrigerator, freezer,
and air conditioner.
      3.   "Small convenience appliance" is an appliance such as a personal
computer, curling iron, blow dryer, portable television, portable radio, clock,
and lamp.
   E.   Space Heaters: No owner, agent or occupant shall allow to be used or
use any portable electric, gas, or oil space heater or any portable, unvented
space heater fueled by natural gas, kerosene, alcohol or other fuel, or wood
burning space heating units.
   F.   Doorways And Windows: From May 1 to September 30 doorways and windows
shall meet the following requirements:
      1.   Every doorway used or intended to be used for ventilation and
opening directly from a dwelling unit to outside space shall have supplied
properly fitting screens having at least 16-gauge mesh and be provided with a
self-closing device.
      2.   Every window or other device with openings to outdoor space, used or
intended to be used for ventilation, shall be supplied with screens having at
least 16-gauge mesh.
      3.   Every basement or cellar window, used or intended to be used for
ventilation, and every other opening to a basement which might provide an entry
for rodents, shall be supplied with a screen or such other device as will
effectively prevent their entrance.
   G.   Storm Windows; Exterior Doors: From November 1 to March 31 every window
serving a habitable room shall be provided with storm windows, except that
insulated windows need not be provided with storm windows. Each exterior door,
other than an insulated door, shall be supplied with a storm door. All such
storm windows and doors shall be maintained in reasonably good repair and shall
be reasonably weathertight.
   H.   Flammable Liquids Within Structure: No owner, agent or occupant of any
dwelling unit shall allow any motorcycle, lawn mower, gas cans or anything that
contains or has contained flammable liquids to be inside the structure at any
time.
   I.   Display Of License: The homeless shelter facility license shall be
displayed in a conspicuous place within the homeless shelter facility at all
times.
   J.   License Transferable: Such license shall be transferable. Every person,
firm, corporation or other organization holding such a license shall give
notice in writing to the inspection department within forty eight (48) hours
after having sold, by land contract or deed, transferred, given away, or
otherwise disposed of ownership or interest in any homeless shelter facility.
Such notice shall include the name and address of the entity succeeding to the
ownership of such homeless shelter facility and shall be accompanied by the
mandatory transfer fee.
   K.   Notice To City Of Nonrenewal Of License: In the event that a licensee
does not seek renewal of the license for the next license year, the licensee
shall provide to the inspection department, prior to the end of license year, a
signed and dated notice on a form provided by the inspection department,
stating that the premises are not subject to licensing for the next license
year. (Ord. 2013-20, 11-18-2013)
3-22-6: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
   A.   Whenever the inspection department determines that there are reasonable
grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provisions of this
chapter or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto, it shall give
notice of such alleged violation to the owner as hereinafter provided. Such
notice shall:
      1.   Be put in writing.
      2.   Include a statement of the reasons why it is being issued.
      3.   Allow a maximum of thirty (30) days for compliance from date of
notice unless weather and climatic conditions require a greater time period.
      4.   Be served upon the owner, either personally or by regular mail.
   B.   Whenever, upon inspection of the licensed homeless shelter facility the
inspection department finds that conditions or practices exist which are in
violation of the provisions of this chapter or of any applicable rules and
regulations pursuant thereto, it shall serve notice in accordance with this
section. This notice shall state that, unless the requirements are complied
with by the specified date, the homeless shelter facility operation shall be
suspended. At the end of the time allowed for correction of any violation
cited, the inspection department shall reinspect the homeless shelter facility,
and, if it is determined that such conditions have not been corrected, the
inspection department shall issue an order suspending the homeless shelter
facility operation for a definite period of time. If, upon reinspection after
suspension, the inspection department finds that the homeless shelter facility
in connection with which the notice was issued is now in compliance with this
chapter and with applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto, it
shall reinstate the license. (Ord. 2013-20, 11-18-2013)
3-22-7: PENALTY:
Each day of violation shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 2013-20,
11-18-2013)
CHAPTER 23
MOBILE VENDORS AND MOBILE FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
3-23-1: Definitions
3-23-2: License Required
3-23-3: Application
3-23-4: Location Restrictions
3-23-5: General Operation Restrictions
3-23-6: Fees and Conditions
3-23-7: Renewal
3-23-8: Enforcement
3-23-9: Records
3-23-10: Suspension, Revocation, or Non-Renewal of License
3-23-1: DEFINITIONS:
In this Chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following words and
terms shall have the following meanings:
 
                           All articles used for food, non-alcoholic drinks, or
                           condiments including ice or water used by humans
FOOD:                      whether simple, mixed, or compound articles used or
                           intended for use as ingredients in the composition
                           or preparation thereof.
                           A restaurant or retail food establishment where
                           ready-to eat food is cooked, wrapped, packaged,
                           processed, served, or sold from a vehicle, car,
MOBILE FOOD ESTABLISHMENT: truck, trailer, cart, or similar portable device
                           which may or should be capable of periodically
                           changing locations. Mobile Food Establishment does
                           not include the home delivery of food and beverage
                           items.
                           The owner, including any corporate or individual
MOBILE VENDOR:             owner, owner's agent, or owner's employees of a
                           Mobile Food Establishment within the City of
                           Menomonie. (Ord. 2021-06, 8-16-2021)
 
3-23-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for a person to operate as a Mobile Vendor and serve,
sell, or distribute food from a Mobile Food Establishment or cook, wrap,
package, process, serve, or portion food in a Mobile Food Establishment in the
City of Menomonie without first having obtained a valid license for the Mobile
Food Establishment from the City Clerk as provided for by this Chapter. (Ord.
2021-06, 8-16-2021)
3-23-3: APPLICATION:
Any person desiring to license a Mobile Food Establishment shall make written
application for a Mobile Food Establishment License to the City Clerk. The
application shall be on the form provided by the City Clerk's office and shall
include the following:
   A.   The name, signature, and address of each applicant and each member or
officer of a corporate applicant.
   B.   A description of the mobile vending vehicle or cart, including the
make, model, VIN number and license plate for mobile vending vehicles to ensure
proper registration.
   C.   A valid copy of all necessary licenses or inspection compliance forms
for the operation of the Mobile Food Establishment, including, but not limited
to, licenses or certificates required by the Menomonie Fire Department, Dunn
County Health Department, the State of Wisconsin, or any subsidiary enforcement
agencies or departments thereof.
   D.   A signed statement that the individual applicant or corporate applicant
shall hold harmless the City of Menomonie, its officers, and employees, and
shall indemnify the City of Menomonie, its officers, and employees for any
claims for damage to property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by
any activity carried on under the terms of the license.
   E.   Proof the applicant has and will maintain such public liability
insurance coverage of not less than $1,000,000.00 covering the Mobile Food
Establishment. Proof of insurance must be included with the application.
   F.   The proposed location of the mobile vending vehicle or cart to be used
in the Mobile Food Establishment and any additional information as deemed
necessary by City of Menomonie staff in their sole discretion. (Ord. 2021-06,
8-16-2021)
3-23-4: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
Except as provided herein, any licensed Mobile Food Establishment and any of
its Mobile Vendors agree to abide by the following restrictions:
   A.   To not operate upon or in the public road right-of-way, public grounds,
or public alleys;
   B.   To ensure no vending takes place in a public street except from the
curbside;
   C.   To comply with all state and municipal traffic and parking laws at all
times;
   D.   To ensure no vending takes place on a State Trunk Highway, U.S. Highway
or County Trunk Highway unless such highway is legally closed for an event;
   E.   To not impede the free use of a sidewalk if operating on a sidewalk or
indicate the Mobile Food Establishment has exclusive rights to a certain
location; and
   F.   In the event the Mobile Food Establishment is operating on private,
nonresidential property, to obtain written consent of the private property
owner. (Ord. 2021-06, 8-16-2021)
3-23-5: GENERAL OPERATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Mobile Food Establishments may be operated between the hours of 8:00
a.m. and 11:00 p.m.
   B.   Any power required for a Mobile Food Establishment shall not be drawn
from the public right-of-way utilities. No power cable or equipment shall be
extended over any City street, alley or sidewalk.
   C.   No Mobile Vendor or Mobile Food Establishment shall use or maintain any
outside sound amplifying equipment, or noisemakers of any kind, while
stationary.
   D.   Mobile Vendors shall be responsible for providing ample trash/refuse
receptacles for its Mobile Food Establishment and shall be responsible for
removing such receptacles at the conclusion of sales. Trash or refuse from the
Mobile Food Establishment's receptacles shall not be placed in any public or
private trash receptacles, including dumpsters, without the private trash
receptacle's owner's consent.
   E.   Mobile Vendors shall take every precaution to ensure that the operation
of their Mobile Food Establishment does not materially affect the peace and
welfare of the general public nor cause any unreasonably loud, disturbing, and/
or unnecessary noise or any other noise of any character, intensity or duration
as to be detrimental or disturbing to the public peace or welfare.
   F.   The Mobile Food Establishment License shall be displayed on the mobile
vending vehicle or cart used for the Mobile Food Establishment during any and
all hours of operation. (Ord. 2021-06, 8-16-2021)
3-23-6: FEES AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   All applicants for a new Mobile Food Establishment License and any
applicants applying for a renewal of their Mobile Food Establishment License
shall pay an annual license fee in the amount of $50.00 and an annual
investigation fee of $10.00.
   B.   Licenses shall commence on January 1 and expire on December 31 of each
calendar year. Licenses applied for and granted after January 1 shall expire on
December 31. License fees shall not be pro-rated.
   C.   The Mobile Food Establishment License is non-transferrable from person
to person or mobile vending vehicle or cart to another mobile vending vehicle
or cart.
   D.   Each Mobile Vendor or Mobile Food Establishment shall be separately
licensed.
   E.   Any Mobile Vendor and any Mobile Food Establishment shall comply with
NFPA-1 Fire Code and Wisconsin Administrative Code SPS 314.50. (Ord. 2021-06,
8-16-2021; amd. Ord. 2024-09, 5-20-2024)
3-23-7: RENEWAL:
The license holder shall, on an annual basis, file a renewal form provided by
the City Clerk's Office and renewal fee as established by the Common Council
prior to the expiration of the license, and such renewal shall be processed in
the same manner as the initial application. (Ord. 2021-06, 8-16-2021)
3-23-8: ENFORCEMENT:
The enforcement of this chapter shall be under the jurisdiction of the Fire
Chief, Police Chief, or Chief Building Inspector, or their designee, who shall
have the power to inspect to determine compliance with this chapter. The
penalty for violation of this chapter shall be a forfeiture of not less than
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00),
plus statutory costs of prosecution. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day on which a violation of this chapter occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2021-06, 8-16-2021; amd. Ord. 2024-09, 5-20-2024)
3-23-9: RECORDS:
The Chief of Police, Fire Chief, or Chief Building Inspector or their designee,
shall report to the City Clerk all violations of this Chapter issued to the
licensee of the Mobile Food Establishment or any Mobile Vendor of the Mobile
Food Establishment. The City Clerk shall note any such violation on the record
of the Mobile Food Establishment and Mobile Vendor. (Ord. 2021-06, 8-16-2021)
3-23-10: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, OR NON-RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   A Mobile Food Establishment License may be suspended, revoked, or not
renewed by the City Council if the applicant or licensee:
      1.   Made any material omission or materially inaccurate statement in the
Mobile Food Establishment License application;
      2.   Made any fraudulent, false, deceptive, or misleading statement or
representation in the course of engaging in mobile food vending;
      3.   Violated any provision of this Chapter; or
      4.   Was convicted of any offense which is directly related to the
licensee's fitness to engage running a Mobile Food Establishment.
   B.   If the Chief of Police, Fire Chief, or Building Inspector or their
designee recommends that the City Clerk suspend, revoke, or not renew a Mobile
Food Establishment License, or, if the City Clerk indicates an intention to
suspend, revoke, or not renew the Mobile Food Establishment License, the City
Clerk shall, in writing, inform the applicant of the intended non-renewal,
suspension or revocation, the reasons, and of the opportunity to request a
hearing before the City Council. Such notice shall be sent by certified and
regular mail to, or personally served upon, the licensee at least ten (10) days
prior to hearing. The City Council shall make the final determination of
whether to not renew, suspend, or revoke said Mobile Food Establishment
License. (Ord. 2021-06, 8-16-2021)
TITLE 4
HEALTH AND SANITATION
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL HEALTH AND NUISANCE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
4-1-1: Unprocessed Agricultural Products, Sales Restrictions
4-1-2: Spitting In Public Places Prohibited
4-1-3: Improper Storage Of Furniture
4-1-4: Curbside Placement Of Recyclable And Nonrecyclable Material
4-1-1: UNPROCESSED AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS, SALES RESTRICTIONS:
No person, firm or corporation, or their agents, shall sell any unprocessed
agricultural products from a temporary location within said City or in
furtherance of such purpose, hire, lease, use or occupy any building,
structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad car, or boat, public room in hotels,
lodging houses, apartments, shops, or any street, alley or other place within
the City for the purpose of such sale without first having given the City
Health Officer an opportunity to inspect the said goods and to receive the
approval of the City Health Officer for their sale. If such approval is given,
the City Health Officer shall deliver evidence of the said approval; which said
evidence shall be displayed at all times during sale of the unprocessed
agricultural products. (1975 Code Ch. 9 § III)
4-1-2: SPITTING IN PUBLIC PLACES PROHIBITED:
No person shall spit or expectorate or deposit or place any sputum, spittle,
saliva, phlegm, mucus, tobacco juice, cigarette stubs, cigar stumps or quids of
tobacco upon the floor or stairway or any part of any public hall or building
in the City or upon the sidewalk or any public street in said City. (1975 Code
Ch. 9 § I)
4-1-3: IMPROPER STORAGE OF FURNITURE:
No person shall place or allow to remain outdoors and exposed to the elements,
any chair, sofa, bed, table or other related or similar furniture, which is not
designed and intended for outdoor use and which is thereby readily susceptible
to deterioration or which thereby provides a harborage for rodents. This
section shall not apply to furniture which is unused and placed outside as
refuse for collection and disposal, or which is in a fully enclosed porch. Each
day of violation shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-13, 6-17-
2019)
4-1-4: CURBSIDE PLACEMENT OF RECYCLABLE AND NONRECYCLABLE MATERIAL:
   A.   Location; Time Limit: No recyclable or nonrecyclable material, whether
or not it is in a container, bag or receptacle, shall be placed for collection
in the traveled portion of the public right-of-way. Such material may be placed
at curbside or immediately adjacent to the traveled portion of the public
right- of-way provided that no such material shall be so placed for longer than
twenty four (24) hours preceding collection or twelve (12) hours after
collection, or, if there is no collection, for more than forty eight (48)
hours.
   B.   Removal For Violation; Cost: If such container, bag or receptacle or
such recyclable or nonrecyclable material shall remain for a period of time not
permitted by this section, the Public Health Officer or designee may cause such
material to be removed and to report the expense of fifty dollars ($50.00) and
the volume based disposal charge established by the City to the City Treasurer-
Comptroller with a description of the lot or parcel of land adjoining which the
same shall have been incurred. The amount of such expense shall be invoiced to
the owner of the property from which such material was removed and, if not paid
within thirty (30) days, shall be entered in the tax roll as a special tax
against said property.
   C.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any provision of this section,
shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) together with the cost of prosecution, for the first offense, and not
more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), together with the cost of prosecution,
for each subsequent offense. These penalties shall be in addition to the cost
of removal of the said material as provided above. (1975 Code Ch. 10 § VIII)
CHAPTER 2
PUBLIC NUISANCES
SECTION:
4-2-1: Public Nuisances Prohibited
4-2-2: Types Of Nuisances Defined
4-2-3: Abatement Of Public Nuisances
4-2-4: Cost Of Abatement
4-2-1: PUBLIC NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
No person shall erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain or permit to exist
any public nuisance within the city. (1975 Code Ch. 10 § I)
4-2-2: TYPES OF NUISANCES DEFINED:
   A.   Public Nuisance: A "public nuisance" is a thing, act, occupation,
condition or use of property which shall continue for such length of time as
to:
      1.   Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose
or safety of the public.
      2.   In any other way render the public insecure in life or in the use of
property.
      3.   Greatly offend the public morals or decency.
      4.   Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to
obstruct, or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway, navigable
body of water or other public way or the use of public property.
   B.   Public Nuisances Affecting Health: The following acts, omissions,
places, conditions and things are hereby specifically declared to be public
health nuisances, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other
health nuisances coming within the definition of subsection A of this section:
      1.   All decayed, harmfully adulterated or unwholesome food or drink sold
or offered for sale to the public.
      2.   Carcasses of animals, birds, fish or fowl not intended for human
consumption or food which are not buried or otherwise disposed of in a sanitary
manner within twenty four (24) hours after death.
      3.   Accumulations of decayed animal or vegetable matter, trash, rubbish,
rotting lumber, bedding, packing material, scrap metal or any material
whatsoever in which flies, mosquitoes, disease carrying insects, rats or other
vermin may breed.
      4.   Privy vaults and garbage cans which are not flytight.
      5.   All noxious weeds and other rank growth of vegetation.
      6.   The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal,
public storm sewer, drainage ditch, or other surface water drainage facilities,
or other body of water by sewage or industrial wastes or other substances.
      7.   Any use of property, substances or things within the city emitting
or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious or disagreeable
odors, gases, effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses
of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or inconvenience the health
of any appreciable number of persons within the city.
      8.   All abandoned wells not securely covered or secured from public use.
      9.   Any use of property which shall cause any nauseous or unwholesome
liquid or substance to flow into or upon any street, gutter, alley, sidewalk or
public place within the city.
   C.   Public Nuisances Offending Morals And Decency: The following acts,
omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby specifically declared to be
public nuisances offending public morals and decency, but such enumeration
shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending public morals and
decency coming within the definition of subsection A of this section:
      1.   All disorderly houses, bawdyhouses, houses of ill fame, gambling
houses and buildings or structures kept or resorted to for the purpose of
prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse or gambling.
      2.   All gambling devices and slot machines.
      3.   Any place or premises within the city where city ordinances or state
laws relating to public health, safety, peace, morals or welfare are openly,
continuously, repeatedly and intentionally violated.
      4.   Any display of nudity within view of individuals from any public
streets, highways, residences or public property.
   D.   Public Nuisances Affecting Peace And Safety: The following acts,
omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby declared to be public
nuisances affecting the peace and safety, but such enumeration shall not be
construed to exclude other nuisances affecting public peace or safety coming
within the provisions of subsection A of this section:
      1.   All unauthorized signs, signals, markings or devices placed or
maintained upon or in view of any public highway or railway crossing which
purport to be or may be mistaken as an official traffic control device,
railroad sign or signal or which, because of color, location, brilliance or
manner of operation, interferes with the effectiveness of any such device, sign
or signal.
      2.   All trees, hedges, billboards or other obstructions which prevent
persons driving vehicles on public streets, alleys or highways from obtaining a
clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or pedestrian crosswalk.
      3.   All limbs of trees which project over and above the surface of a
public sidewalk or street or any other public place, or which interfere with
public vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
      4.   All wires over streets, alleys or public grounds which endanger or
interfere with public vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
      5.   All loud, discordant and unnecessary noises or vibrations of any
kind.
      6.   The keeping or harboring of any animal or fowl which by frequent or
habitual howling, yelping, barking, crowing or making of other noises shall
greatly annoy or disturb a neighborhood or any considerable number of persons
within the city.
      7.   All open and unguarded pits, wells, excavations or unused basements
freely accessible from any public street, alley or sidewalk.
      8.   All abandoned refrigerators or iceboxes from which the doors and
other covers have not been removed or which are not equipped with a device for
opening from the inside.
      9.   Any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public
street, alley or sidewalk or of a public street, alley or sidewalk which causes
large crowds of people to gather, obstructing traffic and free use of the
streets or sidewalks. (1975 Code Ch. 10 § I)
4-2-3: ABATEMENT OF PUBLIC NUISANCES:
   A.   Inspection Of Premises: Whenever complaint is made to the mayor or his
delegate that a public nuisance exists within the city, he shall promptly
notify the appropriate department of the city to forthwith inspect or cause to
be inspected the premises complained of, and such inspector shall make a
written report of his findings to the mayor or his delegate. Whenever
practicable, the inspector shall cause photographs to be made of the premises
and shall file the same in the office of the mayor.
   B.   Summary Abatement:
      1.   Notice To Owner: If the inspecting officer shall determine that a
public nuisance exists within the city and that there is a great and immediate
danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the inspecting
officer shall serve notice on the person causing, permitting or maintaining
such nuisance or upon the owner or occupant of the premises where such nuisance
is caused, permitted or maintained, and if any such persons cannot be located,
shall cause to be posted a copy of said notice on the premises. Such notice
shall direct the person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance or the
owner or occupant of the premises to abate or remove such nuisance in not less
than twenty four (24) hours nor more than one week, and shall state that unless
such nuisance is so abated, the city will cause the same to be abated and will
charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or
maintaining the nuisance, as the case may be.
      2.   Abatement By City: If the nuisance is not abated within the time
provided, or if the owner, occupant or person causing such nuisance cannot be
found, the mayor shall direct the health officer, in case of health nuisances,
and the chief of police, in all other cases, to cause the abatement or removal
of such public nuisance.
   C.   Abatement By Court Action: If the inspecting officer shall determine
that a public nuisance exists on private premises but that the nature of such
nuisance is not such as to threaten great and immediate danger to the public
health, safety, peace, morals or decency, he shall file a written report of his
findings with the mayor, who shall cause the action to abate such nuisance to
be commenced in the name of the city in the Dunn County circuit court, in
accordance with the provisions of chapter 823, Wisconsin statutes.
   D.   Other Methods Not Excluded: Nothing in this title shall be construed as
prohibiting the abatement of public nuisances by the city or its officials in
accordance with the laws of the state of Wisconsin. (1975 Code Ch. 10 § I)
4-2-4: COST OF ABATEMENT:
In addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection,
contrivance, creation, continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance, the
cost of abating a public nuisance by the city shall be collected as a debt from
the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance,
and if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner, such cost
shall be assessed against the real estate as a special charge. (1975 Code
Ch. 10 § I)
CHAPTER 3
SOLID FUEL FIRED OUTDOOR HEATING DEVICES
SECTION:
4-3-1: Intent And Purpose
4-3-2: Definition
4-3-3: Prohibition Of Solid Fuel Fired Outdoor Heating Devices
4-3-4: Nonconforming Use
4-3-5: Enforcement
4-3-6: Penalty
4-3-7: Severability
4-3-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
The common council has the authority to exercise its police powers for the
general health, welfare and safety of the residents of the city. It is
recognized and found that the type of fuel used by and the scale and duration
of the burning by solid fuel fired outdoor heating devices and the smoke and
particulate emissions emanating therefrom create noxious and hazardous smoke,
soot, fumes, odors and air pollution that can be detrimental to citizens'
health, and can deprive neighboring property owners/users of the enjoyment of
