   B.   Other Laws Adopted: There are also hereby adopted by reference the
following sections of the Wisconsin statutes or Wisconsin administrative code
but the prosecution of offenses under this title shall be as provided in
chapters 340 to 349 of the Wisconsin statutes or the Wisconsin administrative
code and the penalty for violation thereof shall be limited to a forfeiture:
      1.   Section 941.01(1), Wisconsin statutes (negligent operation of
vehicle off highway).
      2.   Section 343.44(1), (2)(a), Wisconsin statutes (operating after
revocation or suspension first offense).
      3.   Section 23.33, Wisconsin statutes (all-terrain vehicle regulations).
      4.   Trans 305, Wisconsin administrative code (standards for vehicle
equipment). (1975 Code Ch. 7 § I)
      5.   Sections 194.17 and 194.23, Wisconsin statutes, Trans 325.02(1)-(7),
Trans 326, Trans 327.03(1)-(6), (8)-(10) and Trans 327.05(1)-(3), Wisconsin
administrative code (motor vehicle transportation act and miscellaneous vehicle
regulations). (1975 Code Ch. 7 § I; amd. 2009 Code)
6-1-2: REFERENCES TO STATUTES:
   A.   References to specific statutory sections whenever used in this title
shall mean those statutes and administrative code sections existing as of the
date of the enactment of this title. (1975 Code Ch. 7 § XV; amd. 2009 Code)
   B.   Any future amendments, revisions, or modifications of the statutes
incorporated or made reference to herein are intended to be made part of this
title in order to secure uniform statewide regulation of traffic on the
highways, streets, and alleys of the state of Wisconsin. (1975 Code Ch. 7 § XV)
6-1-3: OPERATION UPON BODY OF WATER 1
:
   A.   Hours Of Operation: (Rep. by Ord. 2014-06, 6-16-2014)
   B.   Manner Of Operation: No person shall operate a motor vehicle or
snowmobile upon any body of water within the city in a careless or negligent
manner, or in any manner likely to endanger the safety of himself or any other
person or any other property.
   C.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any provision of this section
shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than twenty dollars ($20.00)
nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), together with the costs of
prosecution, for the first offense, and not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), together with the costs
of prosecution, for the second offense within a year. (1975 Code Ch.7 §VIII;
amd. 2009 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also chapter 6 of this title.
6-1-4: PEDESTRIAN CROSSING REGULATED:
   A.   Prohibitions: Pursuant to the provisions of section 349.18(4),
Wisconsin statutes, no pedestrian shall:
      1.   Cross a street or highway at any controlled intersection where a "no
pedestrian crossing" sign has been erected; and
      2.   Cross any other street or highway where pedestrian crossing has been
specifically prohibited by signs and/or signals.
   B.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any provision of this section
shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor
more than twenty five dollars ($25.00), together with the cost of prosecution.
(1975 Code Ch.7 §IX; amd. 2009 Code)
6-1-5: SCHOOL BUS OPERATORS, USE OF WARNING LIGHTS:
Pursuant to the authority granted to a municipality in section 349.21(1),
Wisconsin statutes, operators of school buses shall comply with the
requirements of section 346.48(1), Wisconsin statutes, in a residence or
business district when pupils or other authorized passengers are to be loaded
or unloaded at a location at which there are no traffic signals and such
persons must cross the street or highway before being loaded or after being
unloaded. (Ord. 2006-04, 2-6-2006)
6-1-6: SCHOOL CROSSING GUARDS:
   A.    Appointment; Authority: The chief of police shall appoint school
crossing guards. Said guards shall be equipped with regulatory devices and are
authorized to stop traffic of all kinds upon the streets of the city to assist
the safe pedestrian crossing of school students. Said guards shall be
subordinate to and shall obey all orders of any police officer of the city.
   B.   Drivers To Stop: No driver of any vehicle shall fail to stop his
vehicle when directed to do so by any school crossing guard, and no driver of
any vehicle shall again place such vehicle in motion until directed to do so by
said guards. (1975 Code Ch.7 §XX)
6-1-7: TRAINS OBSTRUCTING HIGHWAYS:
   A.   Ten Minute Time Limit: It shall be unlawful to stop any railroad train,
locomotive, or car upon or across any highway or street crossing within the
limits of the city or leave the same standing upon such crossing longer than
ten (10) minutes, except in cases of accident; provided, however, that in cases
of emergency, such as a firetruck or an emergency call, such emergency vehicle
shall have complete right of way and the railroad shall make a passage at the
sound of the siren.
   B.   Penalty: Any railroad company, or any conductor, engineer, brakeman or
other person in charge of such train, or responsible therefor, who shall
violate this section shall forfeit not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), together with costs of prosecution.
(1975 Code Ch.7 §XVII; amd. 2009 Code)
6-1-8: OFF ROAD OPERATION:
   A.   Definitions: The terms "motor vehicle", "highway", "roadway", and
"private road or driveway" shall be, for the purpose of this section, given the
definitions as set forth in chapter 340, Wisconsin statutes.
   B.   Prohibitions; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any person to
operate a motor vehicle on any property, either private or public, other than a
highway, a roadway, or a private road or driveway; provided, however, that
snowmobiles shall not be considered a motor vehicle for the purposes of this
section; provided further, that this section shall not apply to operation of a
motor vehicle on private property with the express or implied permission from
the owner thereof. (1975 Code Ch.7 §XXIV)
6-1-9: TRUCKS, HEAVY TRAFFIC LIMITATION:
Heavy traffic, as defined in section 349.17(2), Wisconsin statutes, shall be
prohibited on the following streets or parts thereof within the city limits,
except that such prohibition shall not apply to heavy traffic using the streets
for the purpose of obtaining orders for supplies or moving or delivering
supplies or commodities to or from any place of business or residence which has
an entrance on such street or highway:
5TH STREET EAST from 21st Avenue southerly to the city limits. (1975 Code Ch. 7
§ XXV)
6-1-10: COMPRESSION BRAKING:
   A.   Definition: A "compression brake", commonly referred as a "jacobs"
brake, "jake" brake, engine brake or dynamic braking device, means a device
primarily on trucks for the conversion of the engine from an internal
combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the
use of or in addition to wheel brakes.
   B.   Use Prohibited: No person shall use a motor vehicle within the city
limits where the compression brake is in any way engaged or activated on such
motor vehicle or any unit which is a part thereof except for the aversion of
imminent danger.
   C.   Penalty: A penalty shall be imposed pursuant to subsection 6-2-3B of
this title. (1975 Code Ch.7 §XXVI)
6-1-11: LOW-SPEED VEHICLE USAGE:
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section, certain words and terms are
defined as follows:
   LOW-SPEED VEHICLE: Shall have the same meaning as provided in section 340.01
(27h), Wisconsin Statutes.
   ROADWAY: Shall have the same meaning as provided in section 340.01(54),
Wisconsin Statutes.
   B.   Operation On Roadway: A low-speed vehicle may be operated on any
roadway that has a speed limit of thirty five (35) miles per hour or less that
is located within the City limits regardless of whether the City has
jurisdiction over the roadway, provided that there is compliance with
subsections C, D and E of this section.
   C.   Speed Limit Limitation: No person may operate a low-speed vehicle on
any roadway at a speed in excess of twenty five (25) miles per hour.
   D.   Driver's License Required: No person may operate a low-speed vehicle on
any roadway unless the person has a valid operator's license pursuant to
section 343.05, Wisconsin Statutes.
   E.   Vehicle License Required: A low-speed vehicle shall be licensed by the
State pursuant to section 341.25, Wisconsin Statutes.
   F.   Penalty For Violation: Any person who violates any provision of this
section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a forfeiture not exceeding two
hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 2010-10, 9-20-2010, eff. 10-1-2010)
6-1-12: ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE AND UTILITY TERRAIN VEHICLE USAGE:
   A.   Intent and Purpose: The intent of purpose of this Section is to
establish All-Terrain and Utility Terrain Vehicle routes in the City and to
regulate the safe operation of All-Terrain and Utility Terrain Vehicles in the
City.
   B.   Authority: The City Council of the City of Menomonie, Dunn County,
Wisconsin, has the specific authority to adopt this All-Terrain and Utility
Terrain Vehicle Ordinance under Wis. Stats. § 23.33(8)(b) and (11).
   C.   Applicability and Enforcement: The provisions of this Section shall
apply to all streets, roads, and highways, hereinafter at times referred to as
City Streets, in the City of Menomonie, Wisconsin which are designated as ATV
and UTV Routes as provided in this Section and the provisions of this Section
shall be enforced by the City of Menomonie Police Department or any other law
enforcement official as set forth in Wis. Stat. § 23.33(12).
      This Section shall not prohibit any law enforcement officer or DNR warden
from proceeding under any other ordinance, regulation, statute, law, or order
that pertains to the subject matter addressed in this Section.
   D.   For the purpose of this Section, the following terms shall have the
following meaning:
      1.   All-Terrain Vehicle ("ATV") shall have the meaning as provided in
Wis. Stat. § 23.33(1)(b).
      2.   Utility Terrain Vehicle ("UTV") shall have the meaning as provided
in Wis. Stat. § 23.33(l)(ng).
   E.   Designation of ATV and UTV Routes: All City maintained roads, streets,
alleys, and highways, including any City maintained parking lots, are
designated as ATV and UTV routes in the City except for the following:
      1.   County Highway B.
      2.   Interstate Highway 94.
      3.   USH 12 from Oak Avenue to the northern City Limits.
      4.   Pine Avenue from Broadway Street to Heller Road.
      5.   Broadway Street from Tainter Street to the northern City Limits.
      6.   Broadway Street from 1st Avenue West to the southern City Limits.
      7.   11th Avenue West from Broadway Street to River Road/Riverview Drive.
      8.   Hudson Road from Hofland Road/ Brickyard Road East to the western
City Limits.
      9.   Crescent Street from Broadway Street to 4th Street East.
      10.   Main Street from 4th Street East to 7th Street East.
      11.   Crescent Street from 7th Street East to 11th Street East.
      12.   4th Avenue from 11th Street East to 13th Street East.
      13.   Stout Road from 13th Street East to the eastern City Limits.
   F.   Route Signs: Under the direction of the City, all ATV and UTV routes
shall be designated by route signs as provided in Wis. Stat. § 23.33 and
Wisconsin Administrative Code NR 64. The route signs shall be provided by the
Dunn County ATV/UTV Association, Inc., or its successor, as provided through an
agreement with the City and shall be installed by the Public Works Department.
The route signs shall be inspected by the City annually and shall be maintained
by the Dunn County ATV/UTV Association, Inc., or its successor. The City shall
be promptly notified by Dunn County ATV/UTV Association, Inc., of any change in
responsibility for maintenance of ATV and UTV route signs.
   G.   Rules and Regulations: The following rules and regulations apply to the
use of ATVs and UTVs in the City and to all areas of operation of ATVs and UTVs
designated in this Section:
      1.   Operators and passengers of ATVs and UTVs must comply with all
federal, state, and local laws, orders, regulations, restrictions, and rules
including, but not limited to, Wis. Stat. § 23.33 and Wisconsin Administrative
Code NR 64. Unless provided otherwise in this Section, all definitions under
Wis. Stat. § 23.33 and Wisconsin Administrative Code NR 64 and any other
applicable Wisconsin Law defining ATVs and UTVs and regulating ATV and UTV use
are hereby incorporated by reference herein.
      2.   ATVs and UTVs must not be operated on the Red Cedar Trail, in public
parks, on public sidewalks, on public multi-purpose trails, on roadway
shoulders, on roadway boulevards, nor on any private property without express
permission from the property owner. ATVs and UTVs owned and operated by the
City of Menomonie, Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources, University of
Wisconsin-Stout, and School District of the Menomonie Area for the purpose of
maintaining these facilities are exempt from this Paragraph. ATVs and UTVs
engaged in snow removal activities on behalf of the adjacent property owner are
exempt from this Paragraph.
      3.   ATVs and UTVs must not be operated at a speed greater than the fixed
or posted speed limits.
      4.   All ATV and UTV operators shall ride in single file.
      5.   ATVs and UTVs may not be operated within the City between the hours
of nine (9:00) p.m. and seven (7:00) a.m.
      6.   ATVs and UTVs are not allowed to park in or along any roadways,
alleyways, or public parking lots within the City between the hours of nine (9:
00) p.m. and seven (7:00) a.m.
      7.   All ATVs and UTVs being operated in the City must be equipped with
head lamps (white light), tail lamps (red light), brake lamps (red light), and
turn signals (amber light in front, red light in back). ATV and UTV operators
must have head lamps and tail lamps turned on at all times.
      8.   All ATV and UTV operators and passengers under the age of eighteen
(18) must wear a Department of Transportation approved helmet.
      9.   All UTV operators and passengers must wear seat belts at all times.
      10.   ATV and UTV operators must possess a valid operator's license as
defined in Wis. Stat. § 340.01(41g), as may be amended from time to time.
      11.   ATV and UTV operators under the age of eighteen (18) must have a
valid ATV/UTV safety certificate in their possession.
      12.   No person may operate an ATV or UTV within the City unless the
owner or operator of the vehicle has in effect, a liability policy covering the
vehicle being operated and such operator has in the operator's immediate
possession a certificate or proof of insurance covering such vehicle which must
be displayed upon demand from any traffic officer.
      13.   No open intoxicants shall be allowed while operating on, or as a
passenger in, any ATV or UTV in the City.
      14.   All Wisconsin Statutes related to the operation of an ATV or UTV
while under the influence of alcohol or a restricted controlled substance will
be strictly enforced, including Absolute Sobriety by ATV and UTV operators
under the age of twenty one (21).
      15.   ATV and UTV operators may tow a trailer in the City so long as the
trailer has working brake lights and tum signals and the width of the trailer
does not exceed the width of the ATV or UTV.
   H.   Closures: The Police Chief shall have the authority to temporarily
close any ATV and UTV route for a period of sixty (60) days or less due to an
emergency, complaint, or other necessary condition as determined by the Police
Chief.
   I.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any provision of this Section
shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties set forth at section 23.33
(13), Wisconsin Statutes, provided, however, for violations of this Section
that are not set forth in the State Statutes, the forfeiture for said violation
shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) together with the costs of
prosecution.
   J.   Severability: If any provision, paragraph, word, or subsection of this
Section is invalidated or deemed unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, the remaining provisions, paragraphs, words, and subsections
shall not be affected and shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. 2016-
12, 8-1-2016; amd. Ord. 2018-06, 5-21-2018; Ord. 2021-07A, 10-4-2021; Ord.
2022-01, 2-7-2022; Ord. 2024-11, 8-5-2024)
6-1-13: MOTOR VEHICLE THEFT PREVENTION:
   A.   Applicability: This section shall apply to any businesses engaged in
the sale, service, rental or storage of motor vehicles.
   B.   Key Control and Security:
      1.   Owners shall take adequate measures to secure motor vehicle keys and
key fobs by securing them in a locked safe, lockbox or locked cabinet during
those hours when the business is not open to the public. Keys shall not be kept
in a lockbox affixed to the vehicle.
      2.   During business hours, owners shall employ adequate key control
procedures so as to prevent the easy access to vehicle keys by unauthorized
persons.
      3.   After-hours key drop boxes shall be constructed and secured in such
a way as to prevent access to keys except by authorized personnel.
      4.   Vehicle keys shall not be left in any vehicles.
   C.   Penalty: Any person who violates any provision of this section shall,
upon conviction, be subject to a forfeiture not to exceed a base forfeiture of
$50.00 plus costs.
   D.   Owner Liability for Investigation and Recovery: In addition to any
other penalties described above, the owner of any vehicle stolen due to the
failure to comply with this section shall be responsible for the law
enforcement costs of investigation and recovery of the vehicle. (Ord 2021-02,
3-15-2021)
CHAPTER 2
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
6-2-1: Official Traffic Signs And Signals
6-2-2: Enforcement; Citations
6-2-3: Violations; Penalties
6-2-1: OFFICIAL TRAFFIC SIGNS AND SIGNALS:
   A.   Whenever traffic regulations created by this code require the erection
of traffic control devices for enforcement, the street department for the city
is hereby authorized and directed to secure, erect and maintain uniform traffic
control devices conforming to the "Uniform Traffic Control Device Manual"
promulgated by the Wisconsin department of transportation giving notice of such
traffic regulations to the users of the streets and highways on which such
regulations apply. Whenever state law grants discretion to local authorities in
erecting or placing of a uniform traffic control device, devices shall be
erected in such locations and in such a manner as in the judgment of the chief
of police of the city will carry out the purposes of this code and give
adequate warning to users of the streets and highways of the city.
   B.   The street department shall have the authority granted by section
349.09, Wisconsin statutes, and is hereby directed to remove, upon the order of
the chief of police, the sign, signal, marking or device placed, maintained or
displayed in violation of this title or section 346.41, Wisconsin statutes.
   C.   The street superintendent for the city is hereby authorized to procure,
erect, and maintain yield signs at such locations in the city as the chief of
police, in his sole discretion, deems necessary in the interest of public
safety. Upon erection of the above described yield sign or signs, the street
superintendent shall file with the city clerk a statement setting forth the
location of each yield sign, the direction of traffic on said street or highway
which is regulated by said yield sign and the date on which the yield sign was
erected. In the event that the chief of police deems it necessary or advisable
in the interest of public safety to remove a yield sign previously erected, the
street superintendent shall file with the city clerk a statement as to the
location of the yield sign to be removed, the street or highway previously
regulated by the yield sign, the direction of the travel on said street or
highway previously regulated, and the date which said yield sign was removed.
(1975 Code Ch. 7 § XII)
6-2-2: ENFORCEMENT; CITATIONS:
This title shall be enforced in accordance with the provisions of sections
345.20 to 345.53, and section 66.0114, Wisconsin statutes.
   A.   Uniform Citation: The uniform traffic citation promulgated under
section 345.11, Wisconsin statutes, shall be used for all moving traffic
violations under this title.
   B.   Parking Citations: Citations for all nonmoving traffic violations under
this title shall conform to section 345.28, Wisconsin statutes, and shall
permit direct mail payment of the applicable minimum forfeiture to the city
police department within two (2) days of the issuance of the citation in lieu
of court appearance. The issuing officer shall specify thereon the amount of
the applicable forfeiture as provided in this title.
   C.   Notice Of Demerit Points And Receipt: Every officer accepting a
forfeiture penalty or money deposit under this title shall receipt therefor in
triplicate as provided in section 345.26, Wisconsin statutes. Every officer
accepting a stipulation under the provisions of this title shall comply with
the provisions of section 345.27, Wisconsin statutes.
   D.   Forfeitures In Treasury; Officer To Post Bond, Qualify: Any officer
accepting deposits or forfeiture penalties under this title shall deliver them
to the clerk of court within twenty (20) days after receipt; except in the case
of nonmoving violations as defined in section 345.28(1), Wisconsin statutes, in
which case the deposits or forfeiture penalties shall be delivered to the
treasurer-comptroller within ten (10) days after receipt. Any officer
authorized to accept deposits under section 345.26, Wisconsin statutes, or this
title, shall qualify by taking the oath prescribed by section 19.01, Wisconsin
statutes, and filing an official bond in the sum of five hundred dollars
($500.00) as described by section 19.01, Wisconsin statutes. (1975 Code Ch. 7
§ XIV; amd. 2009 Code)
6-2-3: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
The penalty for violation of any provision of this title shall be a forfeiture
as hereinafter provided, together with the cost of prosecution imposed as
provided in sections 345.20 to 345.53, Wisconsin statutes.
   A.   Uniform Offenses: Except as provided in subsection D of this section
for nonmoving traffic offenses, forfeitures for violation of any provision of
chapters 341 to 348, Wisconsin statutes, adopted by reference in section 6-1-1A
of this title and Wisconsin administrative code sections adopted by reference
in subsection 6-1-1B of this title, shall conform to forfeitures for violation
of the comparable state offense, including any variations or increases for
second offenses.
   B.   Special Local Regulations: The forfeiture for violation of sections
6-3-1,
6-5-1 and
6-5-2 of this title shall be not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than
two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the first offense and not less than twenty
dollars ($20.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second
and thereafter offense within two (2) years.
   C.   Miscellaneous: The forfeiture for violation of the provisions of
subsection 6-1-1B of this title shall be not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor
more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), except violation of section 343.44(1),
(2)(a), Wisconsin statutes, which shall be not less than one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00) nor more than six hundred dollars ($600.00).
   D.   Parking: The forfeiture for violation of parking regulations in chapter
4 of this title shall be as set forth in subsection 1-4-6A of this code. (1975
Code Ch. 7 § XIII; amd. 2009 Code)

6-3-2: EXHIBITION DRIVING:
   A.   Prohibition: No driver of any vehicle, All-Terrain Vehicle, or Utility
Terrain Vehicle, shall cause, by excessive or unnecessary acceleration, the
tires of such vehicle to spin and emit loud noises or to unnecessarily throw
stones, gravel or other material, nor shall any driver cause to be made by
excessive and unnecessary acceleration any loud noise, such as would disturb
the public peace, nor shall any driver otherwise operate a motor vehicle, All-
Terrain Vehicle, or Utility Terrain Vehicle within the city limits in a manner
that would disturb the public peace or endanger the safety of other motorists,
pedestrians or property. All-Terrain Vehicle and Utility Terrain Vehicle shall
have the same meaning as provided in Section 6-1-12 D.
   B.   Penalty: The penalty provisions of subsection
6-2-3B of this title shall apply to violations of this section. (1975 Code Ch.
7 § XXII; amd. Ord. 2024-12, 9-3-2024)
6-3-3: TURNS PROHIBITED:

      BROADWAY and CRESCENT STREETS. Interconnecting roadway southeast of the
island at the intersection of Broadway and Crescent Streets, no left turn.

amd. 2009 Code)

shall apply to violations of this section. (1975 Code Ch. 7 § XXIII)

6-4-1: PARKING TIME LIMITS:
Whenever signs or parking meters are erected in any block giving notice
thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the period of time
hereinafter specified between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to four
o'clock (4:00) P.M., except on Saturdays, Sundays, New Year's Day, Memorial
Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and except
for such other specified dates as may be established from time to time by
resolution of the common council: (1975 Code Ch. 7 § V)

6-4-7: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
A. Seasonal Parking Restrictions: On all other streets in the City between the
hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. during the
months of November 1 to April 1, parking on one side of the street only is
permitted in the following manner: 1) on odd numbered calendar days of the
month, parking cars, motor vehicles or vehicles of any other kind only on the
side of the streets where odd numbered houses are located is permitted, and
parking on the side of the street of the even numbered houses is prohibited;
and 2) on the even numbered calendar days of the month, parking cars, motor
vehicles or vehicles of any kind shall be permitted on the side of the street
where the houses bear the even numbers, and parking on the side of the street
where the odd numbered houses are located is prohibited. Except in the case of
a snow emergency declared by the Director of Public Works, these seasonal
parking restrictions do not apply to the following streets:
MAIN STREET:
North side, from 10th Street to 13th Street.
South side, from 13th Street to 17th Street. (Ord. 2018-14, 10-1-2018)
   B.   Residence Area Parking Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for the
operator of any hereinafter described vehicle, as defined in section 340.01,
Wisconsin Statutes, to park such vehicle on any street within a residence
district, as defined in section 340.01(50), Wisconsin Statutes, except to
comply with official traffic signs or signals or directions of a traffic
officer or for the purposes of loading, unloading or other business purposes:
      1.   Vehicles in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds' gross weight.
      2.   Motor trucks, trailers or truck tractors with engines or auxiliary
motors operating.
   C.   All Night Parking Prohibited Where Posted: In addition, parking between
the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. of any day
on those streets and portions of streets where it is so designated by official
signs is prohibited.
   D.   Parking Limitations On Municipal Parking Lots: Where signs are erected
in any Municipal parking lot, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than
the period thereon specified.
   E.   Funeral Parking: Authorized funeral homes may reserve on street parking
spaces for use by mourners during funerals through the placement of temporary
"No Parking" signs on metered and unmetered streets. It shall be unlawful for
any person not a mourner to park any vehicle in a parking space so marked.
(1975 Code Ch. 7 §V)
   F.   Statutory Parking Regulations: No person shall violate the provisions
of sections 346.51 through 346.55, Wisconsin Statutes, which are incorporated
herein by reference. (2009 Code; amd. Ord. 2010-2, 1-4-2010)
   G.   No Parking Of Vehicles On Streets For Storage Purposes: No person, firm
or corporation shall use the streets, alleys or any parking place for the
storage of vehicles. A person shall be deemed to be using the streets, alleys
or other public parking places for storage whenever they shall park a vehicle
thereon for a continuous period of twenty four (24) hours or more.
   H.   Parallel Or Angle Parking:
      1.   All cars shall be parked as prescribed in section 346.54, Wisconsin
statutes, excepting upon those streets which have been marked or signed for
angle parking by official markers or signs, when such vehicle shall be parked
at the angle indicated by such markers or signs.
      2.   No trucks, excepting pickup trucks without a platform rack, shall
park in any area designated for angle parking.
   I   Double Parking: There shall be no double parking of automobiles or
trucks on any street for any purpose or purposes excepting for loading and
unloading, and where there is an alley or side street adjacent to the place of
business where the truck is delivering, unloading shall proceed from that alley
or side street; and further provided, that in the event there is a vacant
parking space along the curb anywhere near the immediate location of the place
where the vehicle is loading or unloading, such vehicle shall park at the curb.
   J.   Seasonal Restrictions For 14th Avenue East: No vehicle shall be parked
or left standing on the north side of the 500 block of 14th Avenue East and on
the west one hundred feet (100') of the south side of the 500 block of 14th
Avenue East from November 1 to April 1.
   K.   Front Yard Parking: Front yard parking regulations pursuant to title 4,
chapter 6 of this code shall be regulated pursuant to this title.
   L.   Parking Prohibited On City Owned Property: No stopping, standing or
parking by any vehicle shall be permitted on the following city owned property
lying westerly of the west line of Riverside Drive: From the north line of 1st
Avenue West to seven hundred feet (700') south. (1975 Code Ch. 7 §V)
   M.   Parking Prohibited Except For Loading And Unloading: No stopping,
standing or parking of any vehicle, other than for loading and unloading for a
period of time not to exceed thirty (30) minutes, shall be permitted at the
following locations:
MAIN STREET WEST, 100 block, south side, from 29 feet to 65 feet west of the
west line of Broadway Street.
6TH AVENUE WEST, 100 block, south side, from 96 feet to 124 feet west of the
west line of Broadway Street.
10TH STREET EAST, 1100 block, west side; this restriction applies only between
2:00 P.M. and 4:00 P.M. on days when St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran School is
in session.
14TH AVENUE EAST:
South side, from 74 feet to 94 feet east of the east line of 6th Street East.
South side, from 126 feet to 146 feet east of the east line of 6th Street East.
(Ord. 2016-13, 9-6-2016)
6-4-8: PARKING FOR COMMERCIAL PURPOSES ON STREETS OR LOTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or to park on any street
any vehicle for the primary purpose of displaying advertising, or advertising
with a loudspeaker or other device or instrument or instruments creating an
unusually loud noise therewith.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to park or operate on any street
any vehicle for the purpose of directly selling goods or services if such use
interferes with, obstructs, tends to obstruct or renders dangerous the passage
of vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
   C.   No on street parking place or off street municipal parking lot may be
directly used for any sales purposes except for such locations, for such
purposes and at such times as the common council permits. (1975 Code Ch.7 §V;
amd. 2009 Code)
6-4-9: BUS LOADING OR UNLOADING AREAS DESIGNATED:
The Parking Utility Commission shall have the authority to establish
specifically designated areas in the City for bus loading and unloading
purposes. No stopping, standing or parking by any vehicle other than for bus
loading or unloading shall be permitted in these designated areas. The Parking
Utility Commission shall have the authority to erect necessary signs
designating such use and restrictions. (Ord. 2012-16, 10-15-2012)

6-4-11: PARKING METERS:
   A.   Installation And Use:
      1.   Metering And Use: All streets or part or parts thereof now metered
are hereby approved and confirmed. Additional streets or parts of any street or
streets or Municipal parking lots may be metered as shall hereinafter be
designated by the Parking Utility Commission. The Police Department shall have
charge of the regulation thereof.
      2.   Placement: The meters shall be placed upon the curb next to the
individual parking places and they shall be so constructed as to display a
signal showing legal parking upon deposit therein of proper payment indicated
by instructions on the meters or parking meter kiosks.
      3.   Charges: The charge for parking in parking meter areas on City
streets shall be:
         a.   Fifty cents ($0.50) per hour for all meters which are solely coin
operated; and
         b.   One dollar ($1.00) per hour for all credit card enabled
electronic meters, including parking meter kiosks.
       4.   Unlawfully Parked Vehicles; Exception:
         a.   Whenever any vehicle shall be parked next to a parking meter, the
operator of the vehicle shall park within the area designated by the curb and
street marking lines as indicated for parallel and diagonal parking, and upon
entering the parking space shall immediately deposit in the meter the coin
required to activate the meter. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or
neglect to deposit such coin or to fail to park within the area limits
designated. Such parking space may then be used by such vehicle during the time
limited herein according to the sum thus deposited, and such vehicle shall be
unlawfully parked if it shall remain in such space beyond the period of time
for which the operator shall have deposited such coin in the meter. It shall be
unlawful for any person to cause any vehicle to be unlawfully parked as
provided in this subsection.
         b.   This shall not apply to the vehicles of City officials conducting
official business when said vehicles are displaying an "official business"
permit issued by the Mayor nor to City owned vehicles when engaged in official
business.
         c.   This restriction shall not apply to vehicles engaged in providing
services of construction, installation, maintenance or repair to properties in
the metered area of the City, provided the following conditions are met:
            (1)   The meter for the space used is activated to its full time
limit or one hour, whichever is less.
            (2)   A valid permit is displayed in the right windshield of the
vehicle. Said permit shall be obtained from the City Treasurer-Comptroller for
an annual fee of eighty dollars ($80.00), which may be prorated to twenty
dollars ($20.00) quarterly.
            (3)   The service being provided must be to a property other than
that of the permit holder.
         d.   This restriction shall not apply between the hours of seven
o’clock (7:00) a.m. to five o’clock (5:00) p.m. for vehicles parking in the:
500 Block of S. Broadway; 100 Block of 6th Avenue East; south half of 700 Block
of 4th Street East; 300, 400, and 500 Blocks of Wilson Avenue East; and 300
Block of Crescent Street, when said vehicles are displaying a valid day parking
permit issued by the City Treasurer-Comptroller in the front right windshield
of said vehicle.
      5.   Injuring Meters: It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person
to deface, injure, tamper with, open, break, destroy or impair the usefulness
of any parking meter installed under the terms of this section.
      6.   Use Of Slugs In Meters: It shall be unlawful and an offense to
deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or
metallic substitute for a United States coin.
      7.   Collection Of Monies: The Treasurer-Comptroller of the City shall
collect or cause to be collected the monies deposited in the meters.
      8.   Disposition Of Funds: The money collected from parking meters shall
be used by the Parking Utility Commission to pay for collection of parking
meter funds, for repair, maintenance, replacement and acquisition of new meters
and for the purchase, construction, maintenance and operation of Municipally
owned off street parking lots.
   B.   Enforcement:
      1.   Issuance Of Ticket: It shall be the duty of the Police Department to
take the parking meter number and State vehicle number or other identification
of all vehicles whose operators violate the provisions of this section and to
cause notice thereof to be written in duplicate, leaving one copy with the
operator or his/her vehicle, and the other with the Police Department.
      2.   Continued Violation: In addition to an initial violation of this
chapter, each period of time which is equal to and in excess of the prescribed
parking meter time limit, or two (2) hours, whichever is less, during which a
vehicle remains in violation shall constitute a separate violation of this
provision.
      3.   Payment Of Forfeitures:
         a.   Any person violating subsection A3 or A4 of this section shall
pay a forfeiture in accordance with section
1-4-6 of this Code, by leaving the amount thereof with the Police Department to
be turned over to the City Treasurer-Comptroller and shall be paid within forty
eight (48) hours after the time of delivery of the citation as indicated by the
arresting officer therein.
         b.   Any person violating subsection A5 or A6 of this section shall
pay a forfeiture in accordance with section
1-4-6 of this Code. (1975 Code Ch. 7 § VI; amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 2017-03, 5-1-
2017; Ord. 2019-09, 5-20-2019; Ord. 2022-05, 8-15-2022; Ord. 2025-02, 2-3-2025)
6-4-12: PARKING LIMITATIONS ON MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS:
   A.   When signs or parking meters are erected in any Municipal parking lot,
no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the period thereon specified.
   B.   The Parking Utility Commission of the City shall have the authority to
regulate and specify the parking limitations on all Municipal parking lots and
to erect and post necessary signs or parking meters on said lots designating
such parking limitations. (1975 Code Ch.7 §VII)
6-4-13: PLACEMENT OF SIGNS; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Street Superintendent Authority; Illegally Parked Vehicles:
      1.   The Street Superintendent of the City is authorized to erect in
plain view a sign or signs indicating "No Parking" or a sign or signs
indicating limited or restricted parking at such times and in such places as
he, in his own discretion, deems necessary for the purpose of construction,
removal, repair or maintenance of, under, or upon streets or sidewalks within
the City limits.
      2.   Any vehicle otherwise legally parked prior to the erection of the
above described sign or signs shall be removed from the prohibited, limited or
restricted area by the owner or operator within two (2) hours of the time of
the erection of the prohibiting, limiting or restricting sign or signs. In the
event that said vehicles are not removed within the above set forth time limit,
their presence in the prohibited, limited or restricted areas shall be
considered unlawful and shall be subject to citation and/or towing at the
owner's or operator's expense.
   B.   Chief Of Police Authority: The Chief of Police of the City is
authorized to erect in plain view a sign or signs indicating "No Parking,
Police Order" or a sign or signs indicating limited or restricted parking at
such times and in such places as he, in his own discretion, deems necessary for
the purposes of temporary traffic, pedestrian safety and control, and for
ensuring the availability of parking ample and convenient for voters on an
election day. (1975 Code Ch.7 §V)
