correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when
not otherwise specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained
shall constitute a separate offense.
   B.   The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the
enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (1975 Code Ch. 14 § II; amd. Ord.
2021-10, 12-20-2021)
CHAPTER 4
ELECTRICAL CODE AND ELECTRICIANS
SECTION:
9-4-1: Electrical Inspector
9-4-2: Chief Of Fire Department; Electrical Inspector; Concurrent Powers
9-4-3: Licenses; Deposits; Fees
9-4-4: Municipal Liability
9-4-5: Electrical Permits; Fees
9-4-6: General Scope And Standards For Work; Wiring Methods And Installations
9-4-7: Inspections
9-4-1: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR:
   A.   Appointment: The position of electrical inspector is hereby authorized
and established. The electrical inspector shall be appointed by the mayor and
approved by the common council. (1975 Code Ch. 15 § I; amd. 2009 Code)
   B.   Qualifications:
      1.   The electrical inspector shall be well versed in approved methods of
electrical construction for safety to life, property and the laws and
ordinances pertaining thereto.
      2.   The electrical inspector shall not be interested as a partner or
otherwise with any person or persons, or in any business dealing in electrical
supplies, fixtures or material, or carrying on the trade or work of an
electrician.
   C.   Duties And Powers:
      1.   The said electrical inspector may make or cause to be made a
thorough inspection of any wires or equipment within the city at any time.
      2.   The electrical inspector shall have the power to enter any building
or premises at any reasonable hour in the discharge of his duties. He shall
also have the power to enter any building used in whole or in part for the
purpose of public assemblage when occupied by the public, or at any time in
order to examine electrical equipment in such building.
      3.   The electrical inspector shall issue licenses and permits as
provided in this chapter.
(1975 Code Ch. 15 § I; Ord. 2019-20, 9-16-2019)
9-4-2: CHIEF OF FIRE DEPARTMENT; ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR; CONCURRENT POWERS:
The chief of the fire department or the electrical inspector shall have the
power to cause the removal or repair of all wires, and the discontinuance of
all electrical current, when the circuits interfere with the work of the fire
department or are judged to be a substantial threat to the health and safety of
persons or property.
(Ord. 2007-07, 7-2-2007; Ord. 2019-20, 9-16-2019)
9-4-3: LICENSES; DEPOSITS; FEES:
A. License Required: No person, firm, or corporation shall engage in the
business of installing, altering, or repairing any electric wiring, fixtures or
apparatus for any purpose whatsoever within the city, without first having
procured a license from the Wisconsin Department of Safety and Professional
Services as provided in Wisconsin Statutes section 101.862.
(Ord. 2007-07, 7-2-2007; Ord. 2019-20, 9-16-2019)
9-4-4: MUNICIPAL LIABILITY:
This chapter shall not be construed as assuming any liability on the part of
the city for damages to anyone injured, or any property destroyed by defective
work, material or plan in any building or the permanent equipment thereof.
(1975 Code Ch. 15 § VI; Ord. 2019-20, 9-16-2019)
9-4-5: ELECTRICAL PERMITS; FEES:
   A.   Permit Required: No electrical wiring or other equipment shall be
installed, altered or repaired without first securing a permit therefor from
the electrical inspector, excepting that no permit will be required if total
cost, exclusive of fixtures, is under twenty five dollars ($25.00). This
provision shall not be construed as requiring a permit for equipment or
appliances that merely require "plug in" to be connected with a receptacle. The
application for such permit shall state clearly the work planned, alterations
to be made and equipment and material to be used. All amendments to such plan
must be submitted to and approved by the electrical inspector. All work shall
conform to the plan as approved.
   B.   Application For Permit: Before the inspector shall issue a permit he
shall approve the application so filed with him and issue to the applicant a
statement showing the fees to be paid for such permit, which statement shall be
filed with the city treasurer-comptroller, and the fees therein indicated paid
to the city treasurer-comptroller who shall issue a receipt therefor. Upon
presentation to the inspector of the receipt of the city treasurer-comptroller
showing payment of all legal fees, a permit shall thereupon be issued for the
work set forth in the application.
   C.   To Whom Issued: Such permits shall be issued only to licensed
electrical contractors or to a property owner who is to personally perform the
work on existing premises currently occupied exclusively as residence for
himself and his immediate family. Such permits shall not be transferable. (1975
Code Ch. 15 § VII)
   D.   Permit Fees: The permit fees shall be the same as specified in section
1-9-5 of this code.
   E.   Failure To Obtain Permit: In addition to the provisions of sections
1-4-5 and
1-4-6 of this code, failure to obtain the required permit prior to commencing
the work covered by this chapter shall result in a penalty of double the fee
established by this section, plus an additional twenty five dollar ($25.00)
administrative fee.
   F.   Expiration Of Permit: Permits shall expire 12 months after the date of
issuance, if installation of the electrical wiring has not commenced. (Ord.
2007-07, 7-2-2007; Ord. 2019-20, 9-16-2019; Ord. 2023-15, 4-3-2023; Ord. 2024-
01, 1-8-2024)
9-4-6: GENERAL SCOPE AND STANDARDS FOR WORK; WIRING METHODS AND INSTALLATIONS:
All electrical work shall be installed in conformity with the current and
applicable standards in SPS 316, Wisconsin administrative code, and the then
current edition of (National Fire Protection Association) NFPA 73, electrical
inspection code for existing dwellings, with the exception of the following:
   A.   Installation In Fire Limits:
      1.   Fire Limits Boundaries: All that part of the city as designated in
subsection
9-3-1A of this title.
      2.   Installations: The installations in all buildings in the fire limits
shall be made with type AC or MC cable, types IMC, RMC, FMC or EMT conduit
wiring methods.
(Ord. 2007-07, 7-2-2007; Ord. 2010-05, 6-7-2010; Ord. 2019-20, 9-16-2019)
9-4-7: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Dangerous Wires; Equipment: Whenever the electrical inspector shall
find wires or equipment in a dangerous condition or so placed as to interfere
with the work of the fire department, he may order the persons using or
operating them to place them in a safe and noninterfering condition within
forty eight (48) hours, and on failure to comply with such order or direction,
the inspector shall have authority to order such wires disconnected. Failure to
comply with such orders shall constitute a violation of this chapter. Any
person who shall resist or obstruct any lawful exercise of authority by said
inspector shall be subject to the penalty in title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
   B.   Right Of Entry: The electrical inspector shall have the power to enter
any building or premises at any reasonable hour in the discharge of his duties.
He shall also have the power to enter any building used in whole or in part for
the purpose of public assemblage when occupied by the public, or at any time,
in order to examine electrical equipment in such building. (1975 Code Ch. 15 §
IX)
   C.   General Regulations: Unless otherwise especially permitted by the
inspector, all work shall be left uncovered for examination until examined and
approved by the electrical inspector. Whenever any work is ready for
inspection, the electrical inspector shall be notified by the person receiving
the permit specifying the permit number under which work is being done. The
electrical inspector shall have the privilege of inspecting all electrical
installations previous to and after completion, and he is empowered to have
removed any obstructions, such as laths, plastering, boarding or partitions
which might prevent a perfect inspection. There shall be an electrical
inspection card affixed to the building permit by the electrical inspector
before any electrical work can be covered or concealed.
   D.   Emergency Work: Any contractor doing or causing emergency work to be
done shall report the same to the electrical inspector within one day after the
beginning of the work.
(1975 Code Ch. 15 § IX) (Ord. 2007-07, 7-2-2007; Ord. 2019-20, 9-16-2019)
CHAPTER 5
PLUMBING CODE AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-5-1: State Code Applies
9-5-2: Permit Required
9-5-3: Permit Fees
9-5-4: Issuance Of Permits
9-5-5: Inspection Of Work
9-5-6: Rules, Orders And Regulations
9-5-7: Failure To Obtain Permit
9-5-1: STATE CODE APPLIES:
The construction, reconstruction, installation and alteration of all plumbing,
drainage and plumbing ventilation shall conform to the Wisconsin State Plumbing
Code (SPS 381 through 387, Wisconsin Administrative Code), or any other
additions to the Wisconsin State Plumbing Code, which is hereby made by
reference a part of this chapter. A copy of such code or any future additions
shall be kept on file in the office of the building inspector. (Ord. 2007-08,
7-2-2007; amd. Ord. 2024-01, 1-8-2024)
9-5-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No plumbing or drainage of any kind shall be installed or altered, except that
leakage or stoppage repairs may be made without first securing a permit
therefor from the plumbing inspector, in accordance with this chapter and title
8, chapter 1 (water utility), title 8, chapter 2 (sewer utility), and title 7,
chapters 1 and 2 (public ways) of this code. The application for such permit
shall be on a form furnished by the plumbing inspector and shall state clearly
the work planned and alterations to be made. All later deviations from such
plan must be submitted to and approved by the plumbing inspector. (Ord. 2007-8,
7-2-2007)
9-5-3: PERMIT FEES:
The permit fees shall be the same as specified in section
1-9-5 of this code. (Ord. 2007-08, 7-2-2007; Ord. 2023-16, 4-3-2023)
9-5-4: ISSUANCE OF PERMITS:
   A.   Payment Of Fees: All fees shall be paid to the city treasurer-
comptroller. Upon presentation of the city treasurer- comptroller's receipt
showing that the fees prescribed by this chapter have been paid, the plumbing
inspector, upon entering upon the application the number of the receipt, shall
issue to the owner or his agent a plumbing permit. (1975 Code Ch.17 §II)
   B.   Expiration Of Permit: Permits shall expire if work is not commenced
within one year of the date of issue or if work is not completed within two (2)
years of date of issue. (Ord. 2007-08, 7-2-2007)
   C.   Revocation: If the plumbing inspector shall find at any time the above
mentioned chapters, laws, orders, plans and specifications are not being
complied with, and that the holder of the permit refuses to conform after a
written warning or instruction has been issued to him, he shall revoke the
plumbing permit by written notice posted at the site of the work. When any such
permit is revoked, it shall be unlawful to do any further work thereunder until
the permit is reissued, excepting such work as the plumbing inspector may order
to be done as a condition precedent to the reissuance of the permit, or as he
may require for the preservation of human life and safety.
   D.   Records: The plumbing inspector shall keep a record of all permits,
fees and inspections under this chapter, and shall make an annual report
thereon to the common council. (1975 Code Ch.17 §II)
9-5-5: INSPECTION OF WORK:
Upon completion of the plumbing work on any premises, the person doing such
work shall notify the plumbing inspector when the work is ready for inspection
before such work is covered. The plumbing inspector shall inspect the work by
end of the normal business day following the day of notification, not including
Saturday, Sunday or legal holidays. No person shall use or permit to be used
any plumbing or drainage until it has been inspected and approved by the
plumbing inspector, except for temporary emergency use. (Ord. 2007-08, 7-2-
2007)
9-5-6: RULES, ORDERS AND REGULATIONS:
All regulations and ordinances pertaining to the Menomonie municipal water
department shall be considered part of this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 17 § III)
9-5-7: FAILURE TO OBTAIN PERMIT:
In addition to the provisions of sections
1-4-5 and
1-4-6 of this code, failure to obtain the required permit prior to commencing
the work for any work covered by this chapter shall result in a penalty of
double the fee established by this section, plus an additional twenty five
dollar ($25.00) penalty fee. (Ord. 2007-08, 7-2-2007)
CHAPTER 6
SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS
SECTION:
9-6-1: Definitions
9-6-2: Administration And Enforcement
9-6-3: Allowed Signs
9-6-4: Signs In Public Rights Of Way
9-6-5: Exempt Signs
9-6-6: Prohibited Signs
9-6-7: Required Signs
9-6-8: Prohibited Devices
9-6-9: Tables Related To Sign Regulations
9-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
ABANDONED SIGN: Any sign for a commercial or noncommercial enterprise that is
no longer engaged in business at said location for thirty (30) continuous days.
AWNING: A type of hood or covering over doors or windows, constructed of
flexible fabric or equivalent on a light metal frame(s) which is adjustable or
fixed.
AWNING SIGN: Any sign that is a part of or attached to an awning.
BANNER: Any sign of lightweight fabric, vinyl or similar material that is
intended to promote a special event and mounted to a pole or a building.
National, state or municipal flags, or signs erected by or on behalf of the
city, or the official flag of any educational institution, shall not be
considered a banner. A sign of lightweight fabric, vinyl or similar material
shall not be considered to be a banner; provided, that such material is to be
permanently and completely affixed and adhered to the surface of a solid, rigid
structure and stretched so as to prevent any movement whatsoever.
BID DISTRICT: Business improvement district, a portion of the general
commercial zone defined in resolution 49 adopted November 2, 1992.
BUILDING MARKER: Any sign indicating the name of a building and/or date of,
and/or incidental information about, its construction, which sign is cut into a
masonry surface or made of bronze or other permanent material.
BUILDING SIGN: See definition of Wall Sign.
CANOPY SIGN: Any sign that is a part of or attached to a canopy, marquee, or
other structural protective cover over a door, entrance, or outdoor service
area.
CHANGING SIGN: Shall mean and include electronic message center signs, public
service informational signs, reader board signs, and time and temperature
signs.
DIRECTORY SIGN: A sign which lists and identifies business establishments or
offices within a principal building, shopping center, office park, or
industrial park having three (3) or more such establishments or offices to be
listed.
GROUND SIGN: A sign supported by one, two (2), or three (3) uprights, poles, or
braces placed in or upon the ground surface, and not attached to any part of
any building. Such sign may also be referred to as a freestanding sign,
detached sign or pylon sign. Ground signs with more than three (3) supports
will not be allowed.
HISTORIC DISTRICT: An area as defined in title 2, chapter 8 of this code.
IDENTIFICATION SIGN: A sign that identifies the street number and, when
appropriate, the name of the building.
ILLUMINATED SIGN: A sign designed to give forth any artificial light, or
designed to reflect such light deriving from any source which is intended to
cause such light or reflection.
INFO/DIRECTIONAL SIGN: A sign, generally informational, that has a purpose
secondary to the use of the zone lot on which it is located, such as "no
parking", "entrance", "loading only", "telephone", and other similar
directives. No sign with a commercial message legible from a position off the
zone lot on which the sign is located shall be considered info/directional. An
info/directional sign shall be no larger than six (6) square feet, and be
limited to a maximum height of eight feet (8').
MARQUEE: See definition of Canopy Sign.
MONUMENT SIGN: A ground sign generally having a low profile with no open space
between the ground and the sign and having a sign structure constructed of
masonry, wood, or materials similar in appearance to the building with which it
is associated.
NONCONFORMING SIGN: Any sign that does not conform to the requirements of this
chapter. See subsection 9-6-2F of this chapter.
NUISANCE SIGN: Signs, posters or drawings in the public right of way or on a
property line abutting the public right of way which are tacked, posted, drawn
or otherwise affixed to trees, poles, posts, fences, sidewalks, curbs, fire
hydrants. See section
9-6-4 of this chapter.
OFF PREMISES SIGN: A sign which directs attention to a business, profession,
person, activity, commodity, or service which is conducted, sold, or offered at
a location other than the premises on which the sign is located or the right of
way adjacent thereto.
ON PREMISES SIGN: A sign which directs attention to a business, profession,
person, activity, commodity, or service located on a premises where the sign is
installed and maintained.
PORTABLE SIGN: Any sign not permanently attached to the ground or other
permanent structure; or signs designed to be transported by means of wheels;
signs converted to A- or T-frames; menu and sandwich board signs; umbrellas
used for advertising; and signs attached to or painted on vehicles parked and
visible from the public right of way, unless said vehicle is used in the normal
day to day operations.
POSTER PANEL: A sign erected, constructed or maintained for the purpose of
displaying changeable advertising or off premises outdoor advertising by means
of posters, pictorial, or reading matter, when such sign is supported by
uprights or braces, or attached to a building.
PROJECTING SIGN: A sign other than a canopy sign which projects from and is
supported by a wall of a building, with the face or faces of such sign oriented
on a plane perpendicular to the building wall.
REAL ESTATE SIGN: A temporary on premises sign pertaining to the sale, lease,
or rental of land or buildings.
ROOF SIGN: A sign erected upon or above any portion of the roofline or parapet
wall of a building, and which is wholly or partially supported by said
building.
ROOFLINE: The top of the building wall or the top of the parapet; for buildings
with sloped roofs, whichever forms the top line of the building silhouette,
excluding any minor projections such as chimneys.
SIGN: Any object, device, display, or structure, or part thereof, situated
outdoors or visible from outdoors, which is used to advertise, identify,
display, direct, or attract attention to an object, persons, institution,
organization, business, product, service, event or location by any means,
including words, letters, figures, design, symbols, fixtures, colors,
illumination, or projected images.
SIGN AREA OR COPY AREA: A. The entire area within a single continuous perimeter
enclosing the extreme limits of the message, delineated by lettering,
representations, emblems, or other figures, together with any material or color
forming an integral part of the display or used to differentiate the sign from
the background against which it is placed. Structural members bearing no sign
copy shall not be included.
B. The sign area shall be determined by totaling the square footage of all the
signs (and faces of signs); each face of signs that face two (2) or more
directions shall be counted separately.
SIGN DISTRICTS: A. Residential Sign District: Rules applicable to this sign
district will be enforced in the following Menomonie zoning districts:
   Agricultural
   Limited multiple-family residential
   Multiple-family residential
   Single-family residential
except for those portions of the zoning districts that comprise schools. See
"Institutional Sign District", subsection D of this definition.
B. Commercial Sign District: Rules applicable to this sign district will be
enforced in the following Menomonie zoning districts:
   General commercial
   Local commercial
   Local shopping center
   Neighborhood office
   Technology park specialized industrial
C. Industrial Sign District: Rules applicable to this sign district will be
enforced in the following Menomonie zoning districts:
            General industrial
   Restricted industrial I and II
D. Institutional Sign District: Rules applicable to this sign district will be
enforced on all zone lots that contain schools (public and private; K-12 and
posthigh school institutions) and/or churches.
SIGN HEIGHT: The distance measured vertically from the average grade of the
finished ground elevation to the highest point of the sign; for ground signs
this shall include visual appurtenances which may extend above the sign.
TEMPORARY SIGN: A banner, pennant, poster, board or advertising display
constructed of cloth, canvas, plastic, wallboard, plywood, or other like
materials, and intended to be displayed for a limited period of time. All of
the following signs shall be considered temporary signs and shall meet the
requirements for temporary signs:
A.   Promotional and special event banners.
B.   Signs erected in conjunction with the construction or remodeling of a
building.
C.   Election, referendum and fundraising campaign signs.
D.   Inflatable signs and tethered balloons.
E.   Open house and grand opening signs.
F.   Outdoor sale signs.
G.   Portable signs.
H.   Real estate sale or lease signs.
I.   Temporary window signs.
J.   Thrift sale signs.
VENDING MACHINES: Signs affixed to and designed as an integral part of vending
machines, gasoline pumps, ice or milk containers, newspaper machines, or other
similar machines, indicating only the contents of such devices, the pricing of
the contents contained within, directional or instructional information as to
use or other similar information. Such sign may be illuminated by reflective or
internal means, and shall not extend from or project from such devices. Such
signs shall not be included in the determination of total allowable signage
area for the zone lot upon which the vending machine is located.
VISION TRIANGLE: The area formed by measuring from the intersection of two (2)
property lines at the intersection of two (2) streets to points twenty five
feet (25') along said property lines and then connecting these two (2) points
with a straight line.
WALL SIGN: A sign which is attached directly to a building wall, with the
exposed face of the sign in a plane approximately parallel to the building
wall. A sign mounted upon a sloped roof of a commercial building which is an
integral part of the design of such roof and building, and does not project
above the roofline, shall be considered a wall sign and regulated as such.
WINDOW SIGN: A sign affixed to, in contact with, painted upon, or placed within
a window, for the purpose of viewing from outside the premises; such sign must
be placed only on the interior of any window unless painted directly upon it.
This does not include merchandise located in a window. The area of any
permanent window sign shall not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the window area.
ZONE LOT: A parcel of land in single ownership that is of sufficient size to
meet minimum zoning requirements for area, coverage, and use, and that can
provide such yards and other open spaces as required by the zoning regulations.
(1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX; amd. Ord. 2007-09, 7-16-2007; Ord. 2012-10, 6-4-2012)
9-6-2: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Permits Required: No sign, except those specifically exempted by this
section shall be erected without a permit issued by the city building
inspector's office, application for which shall be accompanied by such scale
drawings (including, but not limited to, site plan, structural details),
photographs, and other information as the building inspector may reasonably
require.
   B.   Historic Preservation Commission: Proposed signs within a historic
district shall require the written approval of the historic preservation
commission prior to the issuance of a permit. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)
   C.   Fees: The fee for a sign permit shall be at the rate of one dollar
($1.00) per square foot of sign area with a minimum fee of twenty five dollars
($25.00). See definition of "sign area or copy area" in section
9-6-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 2007-06, 7-2-2007)
   D.   Permits Not Required: See section
9-6-9, table 1 of this chapter.
   E.   Design, Construction And Maintenance: All signs shall be designed,
constructed, and maintained in accordance with the following standards:
      1.   All signs shall comply with applicable provisions of the Wisconsin
building code and the national electrical code (article 600).
      2.   Except for temporary signs, all signs shall be constructed of
permanent materials and shall be permanently attached to the ground, a
building, or another structure by direct attachment to a rigid wall, frame, or
structure, and shall be maintained in good finish (not faded) and good
structural condition at all times; able to withstand thirty (30) psf of wind
pressure.
      3.   Abandoned signs must be removed or refurbished within thirty (30)
days.
   F.   Nonconforming Existing Signs, Permits And Terms:
      1.   A sign other than temporary sign(s) that would be permitted under
this chapter only with a sign permit, but which was in existence on the
effective date of the original enactment of this chapter (September 25, 1991),
or on the effective date of any applicable amendment thereto, or on a later
date when the property is annexed to the city, and which was constructed in
accordance with this chapter and other applicable laws in effect on the date of
its construction, but which by reason of its size, height, location, design, or
construction is not in conformance with the requirements of this chapter, shall
be allowed to remain in place.
      2.   Such sign(s), which were made nonconforming by the adoption of this
chapter, or as amended, shall be allowed to remain in place, provided that no
action is taken which increases the degree or extent of the nonconformity. A
change in the information on the face of an existing nonconforming sign is
allowed. However, any nonconforming sign shall either be eliminated or made to
conform with the requirements of this chapter when any proposed change, repair,
or maintenance would constitute replacement of more than fifty percent (50%) of
the sign or its supporting structure.
   G.   Violations: Any of the following shall be a violation of this chapter
and shall be subject to the enforcement remedies and penalties provided by this
chapter, by the zoning ordinance, and by state law:
      1.   To erect or maintain any sign in a way that is inconsistent with any
plan or permit governing such sign or the zone lot on which the sign is
located;
      2.   To erect or maintain any sign requiring a permit without such a
permit;
      3.   To fail to remove any sign that is installed, created, erected, or
maintained in violation of this chapter, or in the case of temporary signs, for
which the sign permit has lapsed; or
      4.   To continue any such violation. Each day that each such sign is in
violation shall be considered a separate violation when applying the penalties
of the city zoning regulations.
   H.   Appeals: Appeals may be made to the zoning board of appeals (or
equivalent) by the same rights and procedures governing other zoning appeals.
Appeals shall be reviewed by the building inspector's office which shall advise
the board of its findings prior to the board's decision.
   I.   Additional Regulations: Additional sign regulations exist in title 10,
"Zoning Regulations", of this code. In the event that sign provisions of title
10 conflict with the regulations of this title, the provisions of title 10
shall control. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)
9-6-3: ALLOWED SIGNS:
   A.   Permanent Signs: The following signs whose subject matter relates
exclusively to the premises on which they are located, or to products,
accommodations, or activities on those premises, shall be allowed as follows:
      1.   Permanent signs shall be allowed on private property in the city in
accordance with, and only in accordance with, table 1, section
9-6-9 of this chapter. If the letter "A" appears for a sign type in a column,
such sign is allowed without prior permit approval in the sign districts
represented by that column. If the letter "P" appears for a sign type in a
column, such sign is allowed only with prior permit approval in the sign
districts represented by that column; special conditions may apply in some
cases. If the letters "NA" appear for a sign type in a column, such a sign is
not allowed in the zoning districts represented by that column under any
circumstances.
      2.   Although permitted under subsection A1 of this section, a sign
designated by an "A" or "P" in table 1 shall be allowed only if:
         a.   The sum of the area of all building and freestanding signs on the
zone lot conforms with the maximum permitted sign area as determined by the
formula for the zoning district in which the lot is located as specified in
table 2, section
9-6-9 of this chapter.
         b.   The size, location, height and number of signs on the lot conform
with the requirements of table 3, section
9-6-9 of this chapter, which establishes permitted sign dimensions by sign
type, and with any additional limitations listed in table 1, section
9-6-9 of this chapter.
   B.   Temporary Signs: The following temporary signs are allowed, for the
time period listed; for permit requirements see table 1, section
9-6-9 of this chapter: (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)
      1.   Banners: Banners may be erected no more than thirty (30) days prior
to the special event, and must be removed within five (5) days after the
special event. (Ord. 2007-09, 7-16-2007)
      2.   Construction Signs: One unlighted sign of up to thirty two (32)
square feet identifying parties involved in construction on the premises where
the sign is located (except in residential sign district the limit is 16 square
feet), but not including the advertisement of any product. These signs must be
removed within seven (7) days after substantial completion of construction.
Signs announcing: "Future site of...", fall in this category.
      3.   Election Campaign Signs: Campaign signs may not be erected sooner
than thirty (30) days before any election and must be removed within five (5)
days after any election. Campaign signs shall not be erected within the vision
triangle. No election signs having an electrical, mechanical or audio auxiliary
component shall be permitted. The requirements of tables 2 and 3, section
9-6-9 of this chapter, are inapplicable to campaign signs.
      4.   Inflatable Signs And Tethered Balloons: Such signs and balloons may
be in place up to five (5) days out of any given month; one per zone lot.
      5.   Open House, Grand Opening, Outdoor Sale Signs: Unlighted signs of up
to thirty two (32) square feet (8 square feet in a residential sign district)
displayed on private property and limited to one per zone lot; to be erected no
more than seven (7) days prior to the event; and to be removed within twenty
four (24) hours after the event.
      6.   Portable Signs: One sign per zone lot; must be in place less than
fifty percent (50%) of the time during any given week; the remainder of the
time they must be out of sight (in natural or any artificial light) of the
right of way. Portable signs must meet all setback criteria of this chapter.
      7.   Real Estate Signs: One unlighted sign of up to thirty two (32)
square feet (except in residential sign district the limit is 8 square feet)
pertaining to the sale, rental or lease of the premises on which the sign is
displayed; to be removed within fourteen (14) days after sale, rental or lease.
      8.   Display Window Signs: Signs on the surface of or inside display
windows, lighted only by building illumination and covering no more than fifty
percent (50%) of the display window area.
      9.   Thrift Sale Signs: Signs of up to four (4) square feet, displayed on
private property and only on the date of the sale and one day prior. (1975 Code
Ch. 16 § XIX)
9-6-4: SIGNS IN PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY:
No signs shall be allowed in the public right of way, except for the following:
   A.   Permanent Signs:
      1.   Public signs erected by or on behalf of a governmental body to post
legal notices, identifying public property, convey public information, and
direct or regulate pedestrian or vehicular traffic.
      2.   Signs required or allowed by state (of Wisconsin) statute.
      3.   Informational signs of a public utility regarding its poles, lines,
pipes, or facilities.
      4.   Awning, projecting, and suspended signs projecting over a public
right of way in conformity with the conditions of table 1 and table 4, section
9-6-9 of this chapter.
      5.   Signs permitted by the plan commission under such conditions and
restrictions as the plan commission deems reasonable.
   B.   Temporary Signs: Temporary signs for which a permit is required (see
table 1, section
9-6-9 of this chapter).
   C.   Emergency Signs: Emergency warning signs erected by a governmental
agency, a public utility company, or a contractor doing authorized or permitted
work within the public right of way.
   D.   Other Signs Forfeited: Any sign installed or placed on public property,
except in conformance with this section (including, but not limited to,
nuisance signs), shall be forfeited to the public and subject to confiscation.
In addition to other remedies hereunder, the city shall have the right to
recover from the owner or person placing such a sign the full costs of removal
and disposal of such sign. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)
9-6-5: EXEMPT SIGNS:
The following signs shall be exempt from regulation under this chapter:
   A.   Any public notice or warning required by a valid and applicable
federal, state, or local law, regulation, or ordinance.
   B.   Any sign inside a building, not attached to a window or door, that is
not normally legible from the right of way.
   C.   Works of art that do not include a commercial message.
   D.   Holiday lights and decorations with no commercial message.
   E.   Traffic control signs on private property, such as "stop", "yield", and
similar signs, the faces of which meet department of transportation standards
and which contain no commercial message of any sort.
   F.   Signs attached to or painted on vehicles parked and visible from the
public right of way, if the sign(s) on said vehicles only advertise a nonprofit
organization, including the city. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)
   G.   National, state or municipal flags, or signs erected by or on behalf of
the city, or the official flag of any educational institution. (Ord. 2007-09,
7-16-2007)
   H.   Signs on or adjacent to any ballfield in Wakanda Park and the softball
field at 720 19th Avenue as approved by the recreation advisory board pursuant
to rules and regulations established by the recreation advisory board. (Ord.
2015-03, 3-16-2015; Ord. 2023-04, 3-6-2023)
9-6-6: PROHIBITED SIGNS:
All signs not expressly permitted under this chapter or exempt from regulation
hereunder in accordance with the previous section are prohibited in the city.
Such signs include, but are not limited to:
   A.   Poster panels within the BID district.
   B.   Roof signs.
   C.   Signs within the vision triangle of a traffic intersection.
   D.   Painted wall signs (i.e., signs painted directly onto the permanent
wall material of the building).
   E.   Nuisance signs.
   F.   Off premises portable signs (except as allowed in section
9-6-9, table 1 of this chapter).
   G.   Signs that are in the public right of way except as expressly permitted
in section
9-6-4 of this chapter.
   H.   Signs other than info/directional, within the city's "open development-
conservancy" zoning district(s).
   I.   Signs with a height to width ratio that exceeds one to eight (1:8) or
eight to one (8:1). (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)
   J.   Banners shall not be permitted for permanent signs or temporary signs
under subsections 9-6-3A and B of this chapter, except for the purposes
permitted at subsection 9-6-3B1 of this chapter. (Ord. 2007-09, 7-16-2007)
9-6-7: REQUIRED SIGNS:
The name and street address of any nonresidential building and the names of all
current occupancies of the building must be identified on or legible from the
exterior of the building. See definition of "identification sign" in section
9-6-1 of this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)
9-6-8: PROHIBITED DEVICES:
   A.   No sign shall have visible moving, revolving or rotating parts or
visible mechanical movement of any kind except for the movable hands on street
clocks or temperature gauges or for navigational purposes.
   B.   Strings of lights or pennants not permanently mounted to a rigid
background, except those exempt under subsection 9-6-5D of this chapter.
   C.   Projecting signs in the BID district must be supported by a rigid frame
with no guywire(s).
   D.   Colored lights and illuminated signs employing colors used in traffic
signal lights and fluorescent colors in the yellow, green or red spectrum are
prohibited within view of any signalized intersection.
   E.   Any imitation of official traffic signs or signals and the use of such
words as "stop", "look", "danger", "go slow", "caution", or "warning" are
prohibited.
   F.   No sign shall make noise by mechanical, electrical or wind pressure
means.
   G.   No sign shall have lights or illuminations that flash, move, rotate,
scintillate, blink, flicker, vary in intensity or color or use intermittent
electrical pulsations; provided, however, that changing signs meeting the
requirements of trans 201.15, Wisconsin administrative code, are permissible.
(1975 Code Ch. 16 § XIX)

CHAPTER 7
STREET NAMES; BUILDING NUMBERING
SECTION:
9-7-1: Street Names
9-7-2: Building Numbering
9-7-1: STREET NAMES:
   A.   The name of the street beginning at the junction of 1st Avenue and
Broadway and running north to and including Wilson Creek Drive, and Douglas
Street is hereby changed to North Broadway.
   B.   The name of Railroad Avenue is hereby changed to Douglas Street.
   C.   All streets running east and west, and located north of 1st Avenue
shall be designated as avenues and not streets.
   D.   The unnamed street located in Hopwood's Addition, connecting Tainter
Street and North Broadway (formerly Douglas Street) and located one block south
of Lake Street is hereby named Birch Avenue.
   E.   The numbering of the houses on all the streets north of 1st Avenue in
the city shall commence at 1st Avenue and extend northerly to the city limits.
The first block north of 1st Avenue shall be the one hundred (100) block and
the numbers one hundred (100) to one hundred ninety nine (199) inclusive, shall
be reserved for each succeeding block, being numbered consecutively two hundred
(200), three hundred (300), etc. Wherever there are no cross streets to
designate the blocks, one hundred (100) numbers shall be reserved for
approximately every three hundred thirty feet (330'), and that the same numbers
shall be reserved for each block that is equal distance north from 1st Avenue
whether or not it is on a street which starts from 1st Avenue.
   F.   The houses in the block on the avenues shall be renumbered east and
west from North Broadway, beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block,
and running consecutively for each block on the avenue.
   G.   The name of Gravel Pit Road, from the easterly terminus of Pine Avenue
to the east line of the southwest one-quarter (SW1/4) of the southwest one-
quarter (SW1/4), Section 13, Township 28N, Range 13W is hereby changed to Pine
Avenue.
   H.   That street formerly designated as County Trunk Highway "D" between the
west line of south Broadway and the east line of Bongey Drive is hereby named
28th Avenue West.
   I.   That street formerly designated as County Trunk Highway "D" between the
southern terminus of Bongey Drive and the south city limits is hereby named
Bongey Drive. (1975 Code Ch. 21 § II)
   J.   The common council, after recommendation by the plan commission, shall,
by resolution, name and rename all streets in the city. (Ord. 2005-19, 12-5-
2005)
9-7-2: BUILDING NUMBERING:
   A.   All lots and parcels in the city shall be numbered in accordance with
the building numbering map on file in the office of the building inspector. All
lots, parcels and portions thereof, hereafter platted or otherwise subdivided,
shall be numbered to conform as nearly as possible to the general scheme of
numbering as outlined on said map.
   B.   The owner of any building required by this section to be numbered, and
which is not numbered or is incorrectly numbered, shall forthwith cause the
same to be numbered or renumbered within thirty (30) days of written notice
from the building inspector.
   C.   Building numbers shall not be less than four inches (4") in height and
shall be conspicuously placed above, on or at the side of the main entrance to
the building so that the number can be easily legible or readable from the
street.
   D.   In multiple occupancy buildings the numbering shall be as directed by
the building inspector.
   E.   It shall be the duty of the building inspector to inform any person
applying therefor of the number applicable to any property or building. The
inspector shall keep the building numbering map current and available for
inspection. (1975 Code Ch. 6 § XII)
CHAPTER 8
SWIMMING POOLS
SECTION:
9-8-1: Definition
9-8-2: Permit Required
9-8-3: Fencing
9-8-4: Construction And Structural Design
9-8-1: DEFINITION:
In this chapter, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, "swimming pool"
means a receptacle of water, or an artificial pool of water having a depth
capacity at any point of more than two feet (2'), intended for the immersion or
partial immersion of human beings, and including all appurtenant equipment.
(1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXIV)
9-8-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No swimming pool shall be installed or constructed without a permit having been
issued therefor by the building inspector. The fee for said permit shall be
twenty five dollars ($25.00). Application for such permit shall be made in
writing on forms furnished by the building inspector and shall contain
appropriate plans and specifications, showing the proposed location of the
swimming pool and such other information as the building inspector may require
in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The application shall
generally comply with the standards required of an application for a building
permit insofar as the same is applicable. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXIV)
9-8-3: FENCING:
   A.   All outdoor swimming pools having a depth capacity of two feet (2') or
more, shall be completely enclosed by a fence prior to use of the swimming
pool. The wall of a building may be accepted as a part of the required fence
when found by the inspector to provide a sufficient degree of protection. Such
fence shall be not less than four feet (4') in height above the ground level
immediately below. Such fence shall be of not less than 111/2-gauge chainlink
fencing or such other construction which will make access to the swimming pool
area equally difficult. All fence material and fence posts shall be resistant
to decay and corrosion, and fence posts shall be set in concrete bases or
similarly secured. Any open space between the bottom of the fence and the fence
and the ground shall not exceed four inches (4"). Each fence opening or point
of entry into the pool area enclosure shall be equipped with a gate. Each gate
shall have at least the minimum height required for the fence and shall be
equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices placed at the top of the
gate or at a place which is otherwise inaccessible to small children.
   B.   All such outdoor swimming pools which are located aboveground and
encompassed by an exterior wall having a height of four feet (4') or more shall
be exempt from the provisions of subsection A of this section; provided, that
all such aboveground pools shall be equipped with an effective fence and gate
system at all points of entry to the pool, constructed to the specifications
contained in subsection A of this section.
   C.   Prior to filling with water, each such outdoor swimming pool shall be
enclosed by either fencing as required above, or a temporary construction
fence. Such temporary fence shall be a snow fence or similar design at least
four feet (4') in height and securely anchored in place. The fence shall be
constructed with its base flush to the ground and shall have supportive posts
placed no more than eight feet (8') apart. The fence shall remain in place
until such time as a permanent fence is installed as provided in this section.
The installation of a permanent fence shall take place no later than sixty (60)
days after the initial filling of the swimming pool.
   D.   All persons owning or in charge of a swimming pool for which a fence is
required under this chapter shall construct or provide such fence within ninety
(90) days following the effective date hereof. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXIV)
9-8-4: CONSTRUCTION AND STRUCTURAL DESIGN:
   A.   All swimming pool plumbing and electrical facilities shall be installed
in accordance and compliance with COMM 16, Wisconsin state electrical code, and
COMM 81-84, Wisconsin state plumbing code. All swimming pools, other than
aboveground pools, shall be completely surrounded by a walkway of concrete or
other approved material, at least four feet (4') in width and designed so as to
prevent back drainage into the pool. If drains are provided in such walkways,
they shall not be connected to the recirculation system piping.
   B.   The pool structure shall be engineered and designed to withstand the
expected forces to which it will be subjected. All connections to the city
water supply or sewer system shall be approved by the public works director or
his designee. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXIV; amd. 2009 Code)
CHAPTER 9
LANDSCAPING
SECTION:
9-9-1: Administration
9-9-2: Landscaping Required
9-9-3: Detailed Landscape Plan
9-9-4: Completion Date
9-9-5: Relation To Other Plans
9-9-6: Planting And Seeding
9-9-7: Slopes And Berms
9-9-8: Plant Protection
9-9-9: Woodland Preservation
9-9-10: Location Of Trees
9-9-11: Maintenance
9-9-12: Review Of Landscaping Plan
9-9-13: Violation; Penalty
9-9-14: Exceptions
9-9-15: Appeals
9-9-1: ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Delegation Of Authority: The building inspector is designated to
administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter under the direction of
the plan commission. The building inspector may appoint assistants to aid in
the performance of his duties and may seek the technical advice of the urban
forestry board.
   B.   Inspection Authority: The building inspector or his designated agent is
authorized to enter upon any public or private lands affected by this chapter
to inspect the land to determine whether to approve the plan and after the plan
is implemented to determine compliance with this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 16
§ XXV)
9-9-2: LANDSCAPING REQUIRED:
   A.   New Development: Any new development (including parking lots) in the
local commercial district, local shopping center district, neighborhood office
district, general industrial district, restricted industrial district,
restricted industrial district II, technology park specialized industrial
district, or any residential building of three (3) or more dwelling units in a
limited multiple-family residential district or multiple-family residential
district, or any planned unit development in any district, shall be landscaped
in accordance with this chapter, and an owner shall submit a detailed landscape
plan drawn by a landscape architect, professional nursery person, or other
appropriate design professional as part of the required site plan. Mobile home
parks required to comply and in compliance with subsection 3-17-6I of this
code, shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 2012-10, 6-
4-2012)
   B.   Airport: Landscaping for Menomonie municipal airport shall comply with
the airport overlay zoning district and height limitation ordinance. (1975 Code
Ch. 16 § XXV; amd. 2009 Code)
   C.   Large Addition To Existing Building: If a proposed addition, whether
attached or detached, to any existing building in the local commercial
district, local shopping center district, neighborhood office district, general
industrial district, restricted industrial district, restricted industrial
district II, technology park specialized industrial district, or any
residential building of three (3) or more dwelling units in a limited multiple-
family residential district or multiple-family residential district, or any
planned unit development in any district, except as exempted in subsection A of
this section, is fifty percent (50%) or more of the total square footage of the
existing building, the site shall be landscaped in accordance with this
chapter.
   D.   Small Addition To Existing Building: If a proposed addition, whether
attached or detached, to any existing building in the local commercial
district, local shopping center district, neighborhood office district, general
industrial district, restricted industrial district, restricted industrial
district II, technology park specialized industrial district, or any
residential building of three (3) or more dwelling units in a limited multiple-
family residential district or multiple-family residential district, or any
planned unit development in any district, except as exempted in subsection A of
this section, is twenty percent (20%) to fifty percent (50%) of the total
square footage of the existing building, the site shall be landscaped in
accordance with this chapter, incorporating the following adjustments:
      1.   A fifty percent (50%) reduction in the amount of required trees
(fractions shall be rounded up to the next whole number).
      2.   A fifty percent (50%) reduction in the amount of required shrubs
(fractions shall be rounded up to the next whole number). (Ord. 2012-10, 6-4-
2012)
   E.   Projects Done In Stages: If an addition is undertaken pursuant to a
plan whereby the project is done in stages which, taken together, add up to the
building addition conforming to the limits specified in subsection C or D of
this section, the appropriate subsection shall be complied with by the time the
remodeling under the plan is completed.
   F.   Accumulated Additions; New Construction: Accumulated additions or new
construction that have complied with the landscaping requirements of this
chapter shall be exempt from additional landscaping unless existing plants have
been removed or have been damaged or are in poor health, as determined by the
building inspector. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
   G.   Buffer Area:
      1.   A landscaped buffer area shall be required along the side and rear
yards of any new development (including parking lots) or any addition to any
existing building, whether attached or detached, in any local commercial
district, local shopping center district, neighborhood office district, general
industrial district, restricted industrial district, restricted industrial
district II or technology park specialized industrial district where the above
referenced zoning district, within which the new development or addition is
located, directly abuts any lot zoned single-family residential district. This
landscaping buffer shall be in addition to any other landscaping required in
this chapter. (Ord. 2012-10, 6-4-2012)
      2.   The buffer shall be a minimum of ten feet (10') in width and shall
have a minimum of four (4) canopy trees, six (6) understory trees and sixteen
(16) shrubs evenly spaced across the length of the buffer for each one hundred
feet (100') of length of the required buffer. Fifty percent (50%) of the
understory trees and fifty percent (50%) of the shrubs shall be coniferous.
      3.   A totally site obscuring fence six feet (6') to eight feet (8') in
height to be located along the entire length of the lot line that abuts the
single-family residential zoning district may be substituted for up to seventy
five percent (75%) of the landscape requirements in the buffer area.
      4.   A partially site obscuring fence six feet (6') to eight feet (8') in
height to be located along the entire length of the lot line that abuts the
single-family residential zoning district may be substituted for up to fifty
percent (50%) of the landscape requirements in the buffer area.
      5.   Parking spaces, trash enclosures or any accessory structures are not
allowed in the buffer area.
      6.   Fences used as part of a required landscape buffer shall be
constructed of masonry, ornamental iron, or decorative fiberglass or plastic.
Fences that are wood, sheet steel, woven wire or chain link shall not be
approved.
      7.   For the purposes of this subsection, if a boundary line between
adjacent zoning districts is a public street or public alley, the adjacent
zoning districts shall not be deemed to directly abut one another and the
requirements of subsection G1 through G6 of this section shall not apply
thereto. (Ord. 2008-06, 5-19-2008)
9-9-3: DETAILED LANDSCAPE PLAN:
Such plan shall include the following information:
   A.   The name and address of the property owner, the landscape architect or
designer who prepared the plan.
   B.   The name of the proposed project.
   C.   The date of the landscape plan preparation and any revisions thereto.
   D.   A graphic scale and a north arrow.
   E.   Existing property lines, easements, rights of way, and streets.
   F.   Proposed property lines, easements, rights of way, streets, parking
lots, and signs.
   G.   Existing utilities, aboveground and belowground.
   H.   Proposed utilities, aboveground and belowground.
   I.   A narrative describing the extent of the wooded area on the property,
highlighting existing deciduous trees five inches (5") dbh; and all existing
coniferous trees ten feet (10') or greater in height.
   J.   The location of all proposed plantings.
   K.   A planting schedule showing all symbols intended to represent
plantings, quantities of plant materials, common and botanical names of plant
materials, size and caliper of plant materials, root specifications and special
planting instructions.
   L.   Details of fences, tie walls, planting boxes, retaining walls, tot
lots, picnic areas, berms and other landscape improvements. Where landscape or
manmade materials are used to provide screening or buffers from adjacent
properties or public rights of way, a cross section shall be provided, drawn to
a recognized engineering or architectural scale, illustrating the perspective
of the site from the neighboring property and property line evaluation.
   M.   Details of planting beds and foundation plantings.
   N.   Delineation of sodded areas, seeded areas and wilderness areas
indicating square footage, materials to be used, and seed mixtures. (1975 Code
Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-4: COMPLETION DATE:
All landscaping shall be completed within thirty (30) days after the occupancy
permit has been issued; provided, however, that if an occupancy permit is
issued between September 2 and April 1, then the landscaping shall be completed
by May 1. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-5: RELATION TO OTHER PLANS:
All landscape plans shall be integrated with grading, drainage, site, parking,
signage and other required plans. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-6: PLANTING AND SEEDING:
   A.   Required Landscaping Planting: The number of plant materials required
in order to achieve an appropriate and complete landscape plan for a site shall
be as provided below:
      1.   Every owner shall provide trees at the rate of one tree for each one
hundred feet (100') (or fraction thereof) of the total perimeter of the
property line. The majority of said trees shall be located in the front and
side yards, as defined in the zoning regulations.
      2.   Every owner shall provide a minimum of ten (10) shrubs. The majority
of said shrubs shall be located in the front and side yards, as defined in the
zoning regulations.
      3.   Required plant materials shall consist of ground cover and a mixture
of species of trees and of shrubs, as approved by the building inspector.
   B.   Minimum Size Of Plantings: Plants shall be measured as per "American
Standard For Nursery Stock" (ANSI Z60.1), latest edition. The minimum size of
plantings required by this section shall be as follows:
      1.   Deciduous trees shall have a minimum caliper of one and one- half
inches (11/2").
      2.   Coniferous trees shall be a minimum of four and one-half feet (41/
2') in height.
      3.   Shrubs shall have a minimum pot size of two (2) gallons or
comparable in size if shrubs are bare root.
   C.   Sodding, Seeding And Ground Cover: All open areas not occupied by
buildings, parking or storage shall be sodded, seeded or planted with ground
cover as approved by the building inspector. Exceptions to this requirement may
be permitted when:
      1.   Areas are intended for future expansion, in which case the areas
shall be seeded and protected from soil erosion, and maintained with grass.
      2.   Undisturbed areas containing existing natural vegetation shall be
maintained and kept free of foreign and noxious vegetative materials. (1975
Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-7: SLOPES AND BERMS:
Slopes and berms steeper than one foot (1') vertical for each three feet (3')
horizontal shall not be permitted without special treatment such as terracing
or retaining walls, as approved by the building inspector. (1975 Code Ch. 16
§ XXV)
9-9-8: PLANT PROTECTION:
All shrubs shall be in planting beds. Planting beds shall be provided with
decorative landscaping mulch over a weed barrier and confined with a fixed, in-
place lawn edging, concrete curb, concrete sidewalk, asphaltic pavement, brick,
retaining wall, or any similar hard surface. Said planting bed shall have a one
hundred percent (100%) coverage of decorative landscaping mulch, with the
exception of ground cover and flower beds. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-9: WOODLAND PRESERVATION:
It is the policy of the city to preserve the natural forest and woodland areas
in the city, and with respect to specific site development to retain
substantial tree stands which will be incorporated into the site. Credit for
the retention of existing trees which are of desirable and acceptable minimum
size, species and location may be given by the building inspector to satisfy
other requirements of this chapter. In addition:
   A.   Healthy deciduous shade trees five inches (5") or larger in caliper and
healthy coniferous trees ten feet (10') or greater in height shall be
preserved, unless it is demonstrated to the satisfaction of the building
inspector that they will unduly restrict development of the site.
   B.   All trees destroyed during the development process which were not
identified for destruction in the approved landscape plan shall be replaced in
accordance with the following schedule:
 
Tree Type Size Of Tree Destroyed          Size Of Replacement Tree(s)
          5 to 7 inch diameter (caliper)  One 5- to 7-inch diameter (caliper)
Deciduous tree                            or two 21/2- to 4-inch diameter
                                          (caliper) trees
          8 to 11 inch diameter (caliper) Three 5- to 7-inch diameter
         tree                            (caliper) trees or nine 21/2- to 4-
                                          inch diameter (caliper) trees
          12 inch diameter (caliper) or   Six 5- to 7-inch diameter (caliper)
         larger tree                     trees or twelve 21/2- to 4-inch
                                          diameter (caliper) trees
                                          One 10-foot or taller tree or three
Conifers  10 foot or taller tree          6- to 10-foot trees or six 4- to 6-
                                          foot trees
 
   C.   Structures and other amenities shall be located in such a manner that
the optimum number of existing trees will be preserved.
   D.   Forestation, reforestation and landscaping shall utilize a variety of
tree species and species currently under disease epidemic shall be limited in
use. Species planted shall be hardy under local conditions and compatible with
the local landscape. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-10: LOCATION OF TREES:
The owner shall consider the mature height and spread of trees when planting.
Trees shall be located in such a manner that the tree trunk at maturity shall
be completely within the owner's property. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-11: MAINTENANCE:
The owner shall tend and maintain all plant materials in a healthy growing
condition. Mulch shall be replaced when necessary and kept free from weeds,
refuse, and debris. All plant material which is dying or damaged beyond
recovery shall be replaced within six (6) months or by the next planting
season, whichever comes first. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-12: REVIEW OF LANDSCAPING PLAN:
   A.   The applicant shall submit the landscaping plan to the building
inspector in conjunction with the submission of the building plans. Lack of an
approved landscaping plan will result in no building permit being issued.
   B.   The building inspector, with the assistance of the urban forestry
board, shall determine if the plan is adequate to meet the standards set in
sections
9-9-3 through
9-9-10 of this chapter.
   C.   The building inspector shall inform the applicant in writing whether
the landscape plan is approved or disapproved within ten (10) working days from
the date of receipt of the plan.
      1.   If additional information is required in order to evaluate the
landscape plan, the building inspector shall so notify the applicant and the
applicant shall submit the additional information to the building inspector.
      2.   If the plan is disapproved, the building inspector, with assistance
of the urban forestry board, shall specify in writing the reasons for the
disapproval. The applicant may review the original submitted landscape plan
with the urban forestry board and make the required corrections, resubmit a new
landscaping plan, or may appeal the decision as provided in section
9-9-15 of this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-13: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject
to a forfeiture of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00), and costs of prosecution, for each violation. Each day that
a violation exists or continues shall constitute a separate offense. (1975 Code
Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-14: EXCEPTIONS:
If it is determined by the urban forestry board that the lot cannot support the
required number of trees, the monetary value of the remaining trees required to
be planted will be donated to the city for the purpose of purchasing trees to
be planted in parks, boulevards or adjoining property (with permission of the
owner). Such monetary amount per tree shall be set annually by the urban
forestry board. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
9-9-15: APPEALS:
   A.   Authority: The plan commission shall hear and decide appeals where it
is alleged that there is an error in any order, requirement, decision or
determination made by the building inspector in administering this chapter.
   B.   Procedure: The rules, procedures, duties and powers of the plan
commission shall apply to this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 16 § XXV)
CHAPTER 10
EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL
SECTION:
9-10-1: Authority
9-10-2: Findings And Purpose
9-10-3: Applicability
9-10-4: Definitions
9-10-5: Land Development And Land Disturbing Activities Subject To Control
9-10-6: Erosion Control For Lands Not Otherwise Subject To Chapter
9-10-7: Standards And Criteria
9-10-8: Application And Issuance Of Permits
9-10-9: Time Of Compliance
9-10-10: Administration
9-10-11: Violations; Penalties
9-10-12: Appeals
9-10-13: Severability
9-10-1: AUTHORITY:
This chapter is adopted under the authority granted by section 62.11(5),
Wisconsin statutes. (1975 Code Ch. 24 § I)
9-10-2: FINDINGS AND PURPOSE:
The city finds that urbanizing land uses have accelerated the process of soil
erosion and sediment deposition in the waters of the city. It is, therefore,
declared to be the purpose of this chapter to control and, if possible, prevent
soil erosion and thereby to preserve the natural resources, protect the quality
of public waters, preserve wildlife, protect the tax base and protect and
promote the health, safety and general welfare. The city has determined that
all land development activities or land disturbing activities are subject to
this chapter unless otherwise set forth in this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 24
§ II)
9-10-3: APPLICABILITY:
This chapter applies within the incorporated boundaries of the city and to
major subdivisions subject to extraterritorial review as provided in title 11
of this code. (1975 Code Ch. 24 § III)
9-10-4: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, whenever they occur in this chapter, are defined as
follows:
AGRICULTURAL LAND USES: Alterations or disturbances of land for the production
of food and fiber including, but not limited to, general farming, livestock and
poultry enterprises, grazing, nurseries, horticulture, viticulture, truck
farming, forestry, sod production, cranberry production and wild crop
harvesting and including on site structures necessary to carry out such
activities.
CITY: The city of Menomonie.
CITY BUILDING INSPECTOR: The governmental employee designated by the common
council to administer this chapter and includes assistance from the city
engineer, any other governmental employees designated by the city building
inspector or the common council in the absence of the city building inspector.
CIVIL ENGINEERING: The application of the knowledge of the forces of nature,
principles of mechanics and the properties of materials to the evaluation,
design and construction of civil works for the beneficial uses of mankind.
CONTROL PLAN: A description, approved by the city building inspector with the
assistance of the city engineer, of methods for controlling soil erosion and
sediment caused by or resulting from land development activities or land
disturbing activities.
CUBIC YARDS: The amount of material in excavation or fill measured by the
method of "average end areas".
EROSION CONTROL CHECKLIST PLAN: An optional, simplified erosion control plan,
available from the city building inspector, which is designed to control soil
erosion and sedimentation resulting from land development activities or land
disturbing activities.
EROSION OR SOIL EROSION: The detachment and movement of soil or rock fragments
by water, wind, ice or gravity.
EXCAVATION: Any act by which organic matter, earth, sand, gravel, rock or any
other similar material is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed,
displaced, relocated or bulldozed and shall include the conditions resulting
from the activity.
EXISTING GRADE: The vertical location of the existing ground surface prior to
excavation or filling.
FILL: Any act by which earth, sand, gravel, rock or any other material is
deposited, placed, replaced, pushed, dumped, pulled, transported or moved by
man to a new location and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom.
GOVERNING BODY: The common council of the city of Menomonie.
GRADING: Altering the elevation of the land surface by stripping, excavating,
filling, stockpiling of soil materials or any combination thereof and shall
include the land from which the material was taken or upon which it was placed.
LAND DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITY: Any construction of buildings, roads, parking lots,
paved and unpaved storage areas and similar facilities, including agricultural
facilities as defined in section 281.16(1), Wisconsin statutes.
LAND DISTURBING ACTIVITIES: Any manmade alteration of the land surface of
public or private lands resulting in a change in the topography or existing
vegetative or nonvegetative soil cover, that may result in runoff and lead to
an increase in soil erosion and movement of sediment within the city and into
waters of the state. "Land disturbing activity" includes, but is not limited
to, clearing and grubbing, tilling, removal of vegetative cover, stockpiling of
soil, demolition, excavating, pit trench dewatering, filling and grading
activities, except that the term shall not include such minor land disturbing
activities as home gardens and normal repair and maintenance of private roads.
This term does not include agricultural practices, as defined in section 281.16
(1), Wisconsin statutes.
LAND OCCUPIER: Any person who holds title to land either as sole owner, a
tenant in common or a joint tenant or has title as a trustee, assignee, or has
a land contract vendor's or vendee's interest.
LAND TREATMENT MEASURES: Structural or vegetative practices, or combinations of
both, used to control erosion and sediment production, including areas to be
protected by fencing.
LAND USERS: Persons who use land, individually or collectively, as owners,
operators, lessors, renters or occupiers who are providing a service that
requires access or alterations of the land in order to perform the services, or
by other arrangement which gives them the responsibility of private or public
land use.
PARCEL: All contiguous lands under the ownership or control of a landowner,
land occupier or land user.
PERMIT: A signed, written statement issued under this chapter authorizing the
applicant to conduct land development activities or land disturbing activities
for a specified period of time.
PERMITTEE: Any person to whom a permit is issued under this chapter.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, partnership, joint venture, agency,
unincorporated association, municipal corporation, county or state agency
within Wisconsin, the federal government or any combination thereof.
PLAN COMMISSION: The body established under section 62.23(1), Wisconsin
statutes.
PUBLIC LANDS: All publicly owned lands which are subject to regulation by the
city including, but not limited to:
A.   All lands owned by the city.
B.   All lands which are owned by another unit of government, if that unit of
government or the development project is legally subject to erosion control by
the city under this chapter or by reference under other ordinances.
REMOVAL: Cutting vegetation to the ground or stumps, complete extraction or
killing by spraying.
RUNOFF: The waters derived from rain falling within a tributary drainage basin,
flowing over the surface of the ground or collected in channels, watercourses
or conduits.
SEDIMENT: Solid material, both mineral and organic, that has been deposited by
water, is in suspension in water, is being transported or has been removed from
its site of origin by the process of soil erosion or is discharged into surface
waters from other sources.
SEDIMENTATION: Settling or deposition of sediment.
SOIL LOSS: Soil moved from a given site because of land development activities
or land disturbing activities or by the forces of erosion and redeposited at
another site on land or in a body of water.
STOP WORK ORDER: A method of giving notice to the permittee that one or more
provisions of this chapter have been violated. Notice is given both by posting
upon the lands where the disturbing activity occurs one or more copies of a
poster stating the violation and by mailing a copy of this poster by certified
mail to the permittee at the address shown on the permit.
STORM SEWER: A closed conduit for conducting collected stormwater.
STORMWATER DRAINAGE FACILITY: Any element in a stormwater drainage system which
is made or improved by man.
STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM: All facilities used for conducting runoff to,
through or from a drainage area to the point of final outlet including, but not
limited to, any of the following: conduits and appurtenant features, canals,
channels, ditches, streams, culverts, reservoirs, detention basins, storm
sewers, streets and pumping stations.
STORMWATER RUNOFF: The waters derived from rains falling within a tributary
drainage basin, flowing over the surface of the ground or collected in
channels, watercourses or conduits.
STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS: Works of improvement for land stabilization to prevent
erosion, sediment or runoff which include, but are not limited to, gully
control structures, grass waterways, riprap, detention basins, sediment basins,
flood retention dams, diversions, lining channels with rock, concrete or other
materials. (1975 Code Ch. 24 § IV)
9-10-5: LAND DEVELOPMENT AND LAND DISTURBING ACTIVITIES SUBJECT TO CONTROL:
   A.   Any land occupier or land user who undertakes, begins, commences or
performs land development activities or land disturbing activities, or who
permits another person to do the same, on land subject to this chapter, shall
be subject to the provisions of this chapter.
   B.   The land occupier or land user shall be responsible for compliance with
this chapter by following the procedure of section
9-10-8 of this chapter and by submitting to the city building inspector an
approved control plan and receiving a permit before commencement of any land
development activities or land disturbing activities on lands subject to
control under this chapter. (1975 Code Ch. 24 § V)
9-10-6: EROSION CONTROL FOR LANDS NOT OTHERWISE SUBJECT TO CHAPTER:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, it shall be a violation
of this chapter for any condition to be established, maintained or allowed to
be maintained, that results in excessive runoff or erosion to adjacent land,
public streets or water bodies. Penalties and/or remedies may be sought for
such activities as provided in section
9-10-11 of this chapter. Erosion is excessive when, in the opinion of the city
building inspector, an unsafe condition results in the streets, undue
sedimentation occurs in lakes and streams, or the public health, safety or
general welfare of the citizens of the city is harmed. (1975 Code Ch. 24 § VI)
9-10-7: STANDARDS AND CRITERIA:
   A.   Standard For Erosion And Sediment Control For Land Development
Activities Or Land Disturbing Activities: The city building inspector, with the
assistance of the city engineer, shall review and approve erosion and sediment
control plans based on the following:
      1.   The control plan shall include sufficient measures to minimize
delivery of sediment from the site to adjacent or downstream streets, lands, or
water bodies that, by design, will discharge no more than 5 tons per acre per
year, or to the maximum extent practicable, of the sediment load carried in
runoff from initial grading to final stabilization.
      2.   Established guidelines, standards, and specifications included in,
but not limited to, applicable Storm Water Construction Technical Standards
developed and published by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources.
      3.   This chapter may require all grading, excavating, fills, open cuts,
side slopes and other land disturbances to be mulched, seeded, sodded,
riprapped, or otherwise protected so that erosion and sedimentation are
controlled.
   B.   Standard For Tracking: The city building inspector shall not approve
any plan nor issue a permit for any land development activity or land
disturbing activity under this chapter unless he is satisfied that there will
be adequate provisions to clean up the tracking or dropping of dirt or other
materials from the site onto any public or private street.
   C.   Design Criteria, Engineering Standards And General Principles: The
applicant for a permit may employ any measures necessary to achieve all
applicable standards set out in subsections A and B of this section. However,
these measures will be evaluated to determine whether they follow currently
accepted design criteria and engineering standards. The following general
principles shall be used when evaluating control plans and granting permits
under this chapter:
      1.   The smallest practical area of land shall be exposed at any given
time during development.
      2.   Exposure shall be kept to as short a duration of time as is
practicable.
      3.   Temporary vegetation, mulching or other cover shall be used to
protect high erosion hazard areas exposed during development.
      4.   Permanent vegetative or structural protective measures shall be
installed as soon as possible.
      5.   The plan of development shall relate to the topography and soils of
the site so as to reduce the potential for excessive erosion.
      6.   Adverse impacts on the natural fauna, flora, watercourses, water
regimen and topography of the area caused by the proposed project shall be kept
to the practical minimum.
   D.   Effect Of Compliance: Compliance with the standards and criteria of
this section shall not bar a nuisance action or other civil action brought by
any injured public or private party for damage to property upon which the
erosion directly occurred or to property or other rights which were damaged by
erosion, sedimentation or runoff. (1975 Code Ch. 24 § VII; amd. Ord. 2023-24,
8-21-2023)
9-10-8: APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE OF PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required; Procedure And Fee:
      1.   Unless specifically exempted by this chapter, no land occupier or
land user may undertake a land development activity or land disturbing activity
subject to this chapter without receiving approval of a control plan and a
permit from the city building inspector prior to commencing the proposed land
development activity or land disturbing activity.
      2.   Each land occupier or land user desiring to undertake a regulated
activity subject to this chapter shall submit an application for a permit to
the city building inspector. An application fee as provided in section
1-9-5 of this code shall be submitted to the city building inspector.
      3.   Land occupiers and land users shall be exempt from the requirement
of filing an erosion control plan and shall further be exempt from payment of
the permit fee if all of the conditions, listed as follows, exist. This
exemption is only from the requirements to file an erosion control plan and pay
the fee. This is not to be construed as an exemption from the requirements of
subsection E of this section and subsection
9-10-11C2 of this chapter for erosion control measures.
         a.   The parcel on which construction is to occur is not greater than
one acre.
         b.   The average slope across the parcel in the steepest direction is
not greater than six percent (6%).
         c.   The parcel on which construction is to occur is a lot of a duly
platted subdivision. (1975 Code Ch. 24 § VIII)
   B.   Control Plan Required:
      1.   Unless specifically exempted by this chapter, every applicant for a
permit under subsection A of this section shall develop or have developed and
shall submit a plan to control erosion and sedimentation which would result
from the proposed land development activity or land disturbing activity. This
plan will be administered by the city building inspector with technical
assistance from the director of public works and city engineer.
      2.   If the proposed land development activity or land disturbing
activity involves less than one acre of land, the permit applicant may submit a
simplified erosion control checklist plan on forms available from the city
building inspector. An approved erosion control checklist plan, specifying
